questions.text: A 45-year-old man with type 2 diabetes is started on evaluation for incretin-based therapy to improve postprandial glycemic control. His physician explains that certain gastrointestinal hormones enhance insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells after a meal. Which of the following GI hormones is not responsible for insulin secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) VIP

 

Explanation:

  • VIP mainly causes smooth muscle relaxation, vasodilation, and increased intestinal secretion, but it does not directly stimulate insulin secretion.

  • GLP-1 (Option A) and GIP (Option B) are incretins that enhance insulin release after nutrient intake.

  • CCK (Option D) has a weak insulinotropic effect, especially in the presence of glucose.

 

GI Hormones associated with the secretion of insulin from the pancreas:

 

HORMONE

STIMULI

CELLS

GIP (Gastric inhibitory peptide)

(A.k.a Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide)

Protein, Fats, Carbohydrates.


 

K cells of duodenum and jejunum.

Glucagon-like peptide

L cells in the small intestine.

CCK

Protein, Fats, Acid

I cells in duodenum and jejunum.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of frequent nosebleeds and heavy menstrual periods. She reports prolonged bleeding after minor cuts and has noticed easy bruising. On physical examination, multiple small bruises are on her arms and legs. Which of the following tests is most likely to be abnormal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bleeding Time (BT)

 

Explanation:

  • This presentation suggests a primary hemostasis defect (platelet dysfunction or vWD).

Bleeding Time (BT):

  • Prolonged when platelet number or function is reduced → best screening test for primary hemostasis defect.

Clotting Time (CT) (Option B):

  • Measures overall clot formation (intrinsic + extrinsic); normal in isolated platelet defects. 
  • Normal CT: 8-15 mins.

Prothrombin Time (PT) (Option C):

  • Prolonged only in extrinsic pathway disorders (factor VII deficiency, warfarin therapy). 
  • Normal PT: 11-16 secs.

Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) (Option D):

  • Prolonged in intrinsic pathway defects (hemophilia A/B, heparin therapy). 
  • Normal aPTT: 25-30 secs.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not an absolute contraindication for breast-conserving surgery (BCS)?

choices.text: Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage IIB breast cancer

Explanation:

Breast-conserving surgery (BCS), also known as lumpectomy, involves removing a breast tumor along with a small margin of surrounding healthy tissue while preserving the majority of the breast.

  • The goal is to remove the cancerous cells while maintaining the breast's appearance and function.
  • Performed for early invasive breast cancer (Stage I, IIA, IIB)
  • Absolute Contraindications for breast-conserving surgery (BCS):
    • ​​Pregnancy (Option D ruled out) because after BCS postop radiotherapy will be necessary which is not possible in case pregnancy.
    • Multicentric Disease
    • Diffuse malignant microcalcifications on mammogram suggests widespread disease, making complete excision with clear margins unlikely (Option B ruled out)
    • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast cannot give radiation again, which is essential after BCS (Option A ruled out)
    • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins

questions.text: Which of the following age groups is a greenstick fracture most commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Children before epiphyseal closure

Explanation:

 

  • Greenstick fractures are partial fractures where the bone bends and cracks on one side without breaking completely.
  • They are most common in children due to their growing bones, which have a higher cartilage content, making them more pliable.
  • The presence of epiphyseal plates (growth plates) allows children's bones to bend under stress instead of breaking entirely.

 

Greenstick Fracture

Definition

A greenstick fracture is an incomplete fracture commonly seen in children, where one cortex of the bone is broken while the other cortex remains intact, resembling the bending and partial breaking of a young, flexible bamboo.

Common Sites
  • Most Common Fracture in Children: Occurs before epiphyseal closure, predominantly in children aged 4 to 10 years.
  • Most Affected Bone: Typically involves the forearm bones (radius and ulna).

Clinical Features
  • Patients often present with pain, tenderness, and swelling over the affected area.
  • There may be a limitation in the range of motion.
  • The mechanism of injury often involves a fall or a direct blow to the arm.

Diagnosis
  • X-ray: Shows a small opening or a line at one cortex with the other cortex remaining intact.
  • Radiographic appearance resembles a bending of the bone rather than a complete break.

Analogy

The term "greenstick" is derived from the analogy of young bamboo; when young bamboo is broken, only one cortex breaks, similar to this type of fracture, whereas mature bamboo may break both cortices.

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Treatment typically involves immobilization with a Plaster of Paris (POP) cast.
  • In cases where the intact cortex is also fractured, additional casting may be required to ensure complete healing and prevent complications such as delayed union or non-union.
  • Surgical Intervention: Generally not performed before epiphyseal closure, as conservative management is sufficient for healing.

Prognosis

Greenstick fractures generally heal well with appropriate treatment, and complete recovery is expected within a few weeks, depending on the child's age and bone growth potential.

questions.text: What is the primary objective of the Kishori Shakti Yojana?

choices.text: Promoting higher education among adolescent girls
Ensuring maternal healthcare for pregnant women
Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education
Providing financial assistance for marriage expenses

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Empowering adolescent girls through nutrition and health education

Explanation:

Kishori Shakti Yojana aims to empower adolescent girls through nutrition and health education.

  • Part of the existing ICDS scheme
  • Targets adolescent girls 11-18 years
  • Provides education on health, hygiene, and nutrition
  • Encourages girls to be in school

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field in both eyes. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion affecting the visual pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Left Optic tract

 

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of difficulty seeing objects in the right half of the visual field (nasal from the left field and temporal from the right field ) in both eyes indicates a visual field defect known as Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Optic Tract (lesion posterior to the optic chiasma) affecting fibers from the right visual field of both eyes. The left optic tract carries these fibers (left temporal + right nasal retina).

 

Visual Pathway:

  • Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.


  • Left optic nerve (Option A): Optic nerve lesion → monocular vision loss.

  • Optic chiasma(Option B)→ bitemporal hemianopia.

  • Right Lateral Geniculate Body (Option D)The lateral geniculate body is rarely isolated.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with symptoms of acute onset blurred vision, dry mouth, tachycardia, and urinary retention. His medical history is unremarkable, and he denies any recent illnesses or medication use. On examination, his pupils are dilated and unreactive to light. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Atropine poisoning

Explanation: 

Atropine poisoning (Belladonna poisoning):

  • Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that blocks the action of acetylcholine in the body by binding to muscarinic receptors.
  • In cases of overdose or poisoning, it can cause dry mouth, blurred vision, tachycardia, urinary retention, and dilated pupils, among others.
  • It is treated with physostigmine, which increases ACh levels; it can even cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) to reverse the CNS effects of atropine poisoning.

 

Cocaine toxicity (Option A): Here the patient is hyperexcitable with tachycardia due to sympathetic discharge.  

Opioids (Option B): Here, the pupils are not dilated; rather, they are constricted or miotic. 

Benzodiazepines (Option C): Here, the hallmark feature is respiratory depression.

questions.text: Which of the following agents inhibits the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response but does not have any effect of its own?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Drug C

Drug C (Option C): Antagonist


 
  • It prevents the action of an agonist on a receptor or the subsequent response, but does not have any effect of its own. 
  • E.g. Naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist

Drug A (Option A): Agonist

 
  • It activates a receptor to produce an effect similar to the physiological signal molecule (e.g., morphine at opioid receptors).

Drug D (Option D): Inverse Agonist


 
  • It activates a receptor to produce an effect opposite to that of an agonist (e.g., Rimonabant at cannabinoid receptors).

Drug B (Option B): Partial Agonist
  • It activates a receptor to produce a submaximal effect and can block the action of a full agonist (e.g., Buprenorphine at opioid receptors).

Super Agonist
  • Not directly relevant to opioid overdose treatment but produces a maximum response greater than that of the endogenous agonist (e.g., BMS-986121 at GLP-1 receptors).

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presented with behavioral changes and involuntary movements over the past several weeks. Neurological examination revealed ataxia and myoclonus. He passed away after 4 months, and biopsy findings of the brain tissue are shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?




	Proteinaceous particles with single-stranded RNA cause it.
	It results from the misfolding of PrPsc to PrPc.
	Spongiform transformation is a characteristic histopathological feature
	It is associated with a good prognosis if diagnosed early.
	Familial forms are associated with specific genetic mutations.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in this clinical presentation is Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), a prion disease.

 

Prion Disease or Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathy (TSE):

  • Prions are proteinaceous infectious particles with no RNA/DNA.
  • Pathogenesis: Misfolding of normal prion protein (PrPc) to form beta-pleated configuration (PrPSc).
  • Histopathology: Spongiform vacuolisation inside the cell.
  • Associated diseases:

Types of prion disease
1. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (M/C)

  • Genetic: Familial form caused by PRNP mutation.
  • Transmission: Iatrogenic
  • Symptoms:
    • Dementia.
    • Associated pronounced involuntary jerking muscle contractions on sudden stimulation (startle myoclonus) and cerebellar dysfunction (ataxia).
  • Histopathogenesis:
    • Spongiform transformation of the cerebral cortex.
  • Prognosis: Uniformly fatal with average survival < 7 months after the onset of symptoms.

2. Kuru disease

  • PAS & Congo: red positive.
  • Kuru plaques: Extracellular aggregated abnormal PrP.

3. Fatal familial insomnia

4. Bovine spongiform encephalopathy

questions.text: A 35-year-old veterinarian presents with intermittent fever, sweating, and joint pain. Blood cultures are performed, but the initial results are negative. Further laboratory tests show a significant titer of 640 in the Standard Agglutination Test (SAT). Which of the following characteristics is least likely associated with the causative organism?

choices.text: Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ferments carbohydrates

 

Explanation:

  • Brucella does not typically ferment carbohydrates.
  • Therefore, it is the characteristic least likely associated with Brucellae.

 

Brucella features:

Brucella melitensis is the most pathogenic species for humans.

 

Characteristics of Brucella:

 

Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli (Option A ruled out)

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes (Option D ruled out)

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive (Option B ruled out)

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

 

Zoonotic Nature: Primarily affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, and pigs. Humans can become infected through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products

 

Clinical Presentation in Humans:

  • Symptoms: Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, and joint pain
  • Also known as Undulant fever, Mediterranean fever, Maltese fever
  • Diagnosis is challenging due to nonspecific symptoms and relies on high clinical suspicion

Diagnosis of Brucellosis:

Laboratory Testing Methods:

  • Blood Culture:
    • Most definitive diagnostic method
    • Requires trypticase soy broth or brucella broth in biphasic blood culture bottles (e.g., Castaneda method)
    • Large blood volume (5 ml) recommended due to low bacterial load
    • Incubation at 37°C under 5-10% CO2 for at least 6-8 weeks
    • Positive in approximately 30-50% of cases
    • Bone marrow cultures may have a higher yield
  • Serological Tests:
    • Used when culture methods are unsuccessful

Serological Test Types:

 

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Treatment of Brucellosis:

  • Antibiotics:
    • Standard treatment for adults: Doxycycline for 45 days and intramuscular streptomycin daily for the first two weeks
    • Children: Cotrimoxazole with rifampicin or gentamycin

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. During the examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is measured at 28 mmHg in both eyes. The ophthalmologist diagnoses him with primary open-angle glaucoma. Which of the following medications is primarily designed to lower intraocular pressure by reducing the production of aqueous humor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acetazolamide

Explanation:

Medical management of Glaucoma
Topical drugs
  • Beta-blockers: Decrease the formation of aqueous humour.
    • Eg: Timolol, betaxolol
  • Alpha agonists: Have dual action i.e. they decrease the formation of aqueous and increase the trabecular outflow.
    • Eg: Adrenaline/epinephrine, dipivefrin, brimonidine, and apraclonidine
  • Miotics: These increase the trabecular outflow and open the angle blockage.
    • Eg: Pilocarpine (Option B ruled out)
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: These decrease the formation of aqueous.
    • Eg: Dorzolamide and Brinzolamide
  • Newer anti-glaucoma drugs:
    • Netarsudil: Increases the trabecular outflow and also decreases the aqueous production.
    • PGF2 alpha agonist: It increases the uveoscleral outflow
      • For eg- Latanoprost, bimatoprost, travoprost (Option A ruled out), tafluprost, and unoprostone isopropyl (Option D ruled out)
Systemic drugs
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
    • ​​​​​​​Eg: Acetazolamide
  • Hyperosmotic agents: These draw aqueous out of the eye

questions.text: A 55 year old man, a former construction worker, presents with shoulder pain and limited range of motion. His examination finding is shown below in the image and there is tenderness over the lateral aspect of his ribcage. Which muscle is most likely compromised in function, and what nerve injury could be contributing to his condition?

choices.text: Pectoralis Major; Medial pectoral nerve injury
Pectoralis Minor; Lateral pectoral nerve injury
Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serratus Anterior; Long thoracic nerve injury

 

Explanation:

  • Serratus Anterior is essential for stabilizing the scapula and upward rotation.

  • Serratus anterior is supplied by the long thoracic nerve (C5–C7).

  • Function: protraction + upward rotation of scapula → necessary for abduction >90°.

  • Winging indicates weakness due to long thoracic nerve injury, common in repetitive overhead activities.

Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, and Subclavius (Options A, B, C) do not cause scapular winging 

  • Pectoralis Major: 

    • Functions in adduction and internal rotation of the arm.

  • Pectoralis Minor: 

    • ​​​​​​​Depresses and protracts the scapula.

  • Subclavius: 

    • ​​​​​​​Anchors and depresses the clavicle, but has minimal action on scapula positioning.

questions.text: In a Lineweaver-Burk plot for an enzyme experiencing non-competitive inhibition, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot increases, but the y-intercept remains the same.
The y-intercept increases while Km remains constant and the slope increases.
Both the slope and the y-intercept increase.
The slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot decreases while the y-intercept increases.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The y-intercept increases while Km remains constant and the slope increases.

Explanation:

Non-competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an enzyme at a site other than the active site, which is called an allosteric site. This binding changes the enzyme's shape and reduces its activity, regardless of whether the substrate is present.

 

Effect on the Lineweaver-Burk Plot:

 

The lineweaver burk plot is graphical representation of enzyme kinetics representing Vmax and Km.

  • Effect on Vmax: The y-intercept of the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which represents 1/Vmax increases as Vmax decreases.
  • Effect on Km: The slope of the plot, which is Km/Vmax, remains constant because Km does not change.

 

The y-intercept increases while the Km remains constant for non competitive inhibition.

 

 

Examples of non-competitive inhibitors:

  • Cyanide acts as a non-competitive inhibitor by binding to a site on cytochrome c oxidase that is not the active site, thereby disrupting its function.
  • Fluoride functions as a non-competitive inhibitor by chelating essential metal ions (magnesium or manganese) required for enolase activity, thus inhibiting the enzyme.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hypertension and hypokalemia. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs). Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia due to a mutation in the genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs), leading to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Liddle Syndrome (Option B)

  • Rare genetic disorder causing high blood pressure and low potassium levels.
  • Caused by a mutation in genes coding for epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs) in kidneys.
  • Leads to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Hyperaldosteronism

  • Characterized by excessive aldosterone secretion.
  • Also a cause of high blood pressure and low potassium levels.
  • Classified into primary and secondary types.

Feature

Primary Hyperaldosteronism (Option A)

Secondary Hyperaldosteronism (Option D)

Cause

Adrenal gland disorders

High plasma renin activity conditions

Examples

Adenomas, adrenal hyperplasia, carcinoma, Glucocorticoid-Remediable Aldosteronism (Option C)

Cirrhosis, heart failure, nephrosis, salt-losing adrenogenital syndrome

Renin Activity

Suppressed

Elevated

GRA Mechanism

Hybrid gene sensitive to ACTH

Not applicable

ECF Volume

Normal or increased

Decreased

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with an erythematous, swollen patch in a skin lesion on the face, along with significant oedema of the hands and feet. She reports the patch has been present for several months now, but has only recently turned painful and red. Additionally, the patient experiences pain and tenderness along multiple nerves and reports a general feeling of fatigue and malaise. The patient has been on regular medications but is unsure about their names. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type 1 lepra reaction

 

Explanation:

  • History of a pre-existing skin lesion on the face turning red and swollen, along with significant oedema of the hands and feet, is indicative of Type 1 lepra reaction
  • Pain and tenderness over multiple nerves are other characteristic features of Type 1 lepra reaction.
  • Type 1 lepra reaction is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, that typically occurs in patients with borderline leprosy (BT, BB, or BL disease).
  • It is characterized by an inflammatory response to Mycobacterium leprae antigens usually seen on starting MDT, resulting in a sudden exacerbation of pre-existing skin lesions and nerve involvement.


Cellulitis (Option A):Acute, painful, red swelling of skin and subcutis, usually post-injury; differs from lepra reaction in presentation.


Psoriasis (Option C):

  • It is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by red, scaly patches on the skin, over the elbows, knees, scalp, and lower back. 


Erythema multiforme (Option D): Hypersensitivity reaction with target lesions, often post-infection or drug-related; not consistent with leprosy reaction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a sensation of a bulge in her vaginal area, which worsens on straining. On examination, a protrusion of the vaginal apex beyond the hymen is noted. There is no associated urinary incontinence. What is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension

Explanation:

Vaginal hysterectomy, along with uterosacral suspension, which treat prolapse and support the vaginal apex, respectively, are preferred in post-menopausal women presenting with vault prolapse.

 

Treatment options for vault prolapse in females

Treatment Option

Indications

Conservative (pelvic floor exercises) (Option A)

Mild prolapse, asymptomatic, patient preference

Pessary fitting (Option B)

Symptomatic prolapse, desire for non-surgical management in mild to moderate cases.

Vaginal hysterectomy and uterosacral suspension

Significant prolapse, symptomatic, desire for definitive surgical correction

McCall culdoplasty (Option D)

Significant posterior vaginal wall prolapse, desire for surgical repair in which preservation of the uterus is desired.

Sacrocolpopexy

Severe prolapse, previous failed repairs, desire for durable support

Colpocleisis

Elderly or frail patients, desire for definitive closure of the vagina

questions.text: During a vaginal breech delivery, you encounter a case where one of the baby's arms is extended behind the fetal head, causing difficulty in delivery. What technique is used to manage extended arms in this breech delivery scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lovset's maneuver

Explanation:

In a vaginal breech delivery scenario where one of the baby's arms is extended behind the fetal head, causing difficulty in delivery, the technique typically used to manage this situation is Lovset's manoeuvre.

  • Principle:
    • Due to the curved birth canal, one shoulder remains above the pubic bone while the other is below the sacral promontory. Rotating the fetal trunk with the back anterior and applying downward traction brings the posterior shoulder below the symphysis pubis.
  • Procedure:
    • Lift the baby, induce lateral flexion, rotate the trunk 180° to bring the posterior arm under the pubic arch, and hook out. Rotate the trunk opposite, keeping the back anterior, to deliver the anterior shoulder under the symphysis pubis.

Classical manoeuvre (Option A):

  • This typically involves bringing down an arm extended alongside the fetal head to facilitate delivery.
  • It is a traditional method used in breech deliveries, but it may be challenging if the arm is positioned behind the head.

Pinard's manoeuvre (Option C):

  • This manoeuvre resolves shoulder dystocia by applying pressure to the anterior shoulder to rotate it internally or manipulate it for delivery.
  • It may be used in some breech deliveries but is not specifically for managing extended arms.

Duhrssen's incision (Option D): 

  • This refers to a surgical incision made in the cervix or lower uterine segment to facilitate delivery in cases of severe obstruction or dystocia.
  • It is not directly related to managing extended arms in breech deliveries.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with complaints of severe morning headache associated with nausea, vomiting and seizure. On examination, the doctor suspected a brain tumour and suggested an MRI, which revealed a tumour at the vermis region. Which of the following syndromes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Turcot’s syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The above features suggest Medulloblastoma, the most common type of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET) and the most common malignant pediatric brain tumour.
  • It predominantly occurs in the first decade of life, with a second peak around age 30.
  • Histology: Characterized by densely packed small round cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm.
  • Location: Typically found in the cerebellum (vermis) in children and the lateral cerebellar hemisphere in adults.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include headache, vomiting, nausea, weakness, papilledema, and ataxia.
  • Diagnosis: MRI is used for imaging.
  • Management: Treatment involves surgical resection followed by radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
  • Association: Medulloblastoma is associated with Turcot's syndrome.

questions.text: Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) like Face shields, goggles, gloves and hazmat suits are disposed of in which colour bin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Red

Explanation:

Most personal protective equipment (PPE), like shoe covers, head covers, disposable linen gowns, and masks, is disposed of in a yellow bag, whereas face shields, goggles, gloves, and hazmat suits are disposed in a red bag as they are considered infected plastic waste.

 

Category

Type of BMW

Nature of Treatment

Yellow
  • Used masks, headcovers/caps, shoe covers, disposable linen gowns
  • Waste contaminated with body/body fluids of COVID-19 patients.
  • Incineration/plasma pyrolysis or deep burial.

Red

  • PPE such as goggles, face shields, splash proof aprons, plastic coveralls, Hazmat suits, nitrile gloves.
  • Autoclaving or microwaving/hydroclaving, and then sent for recycling (not to landfill).

White
  • White sharps, including metals.
  • Auto or dry heat sterilization followed by shredding and mutilation or encapsulation.

Blue
  • Glassware, metallic body implants.
  • Disinfection or autoclaving/microwaving, hydroclaving and then sent to recycling.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found dead at home. On examination, his postmortem staining is as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Carbon monoxide poisoning

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Cherry-red discoloration
  • Cherry-red discoloration of the skin and tissues is characteristic of carbon monoxide poisoning due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin (COHb), particularly when levels exceed 30%.

Postmortem Staining in Poisoning Cases

  • Postmortem staining (Livor mortis) is the skin discoloration after death due to blood settling in dependent areas.
  • The color of the staining can indicate certain types of poisoning:

Poison

Postmortem Staining Characteristics

Opium (Option A ruled out)

Purple or blackish staining

Carbon monoxide (Option C)

Cherry red discoloration (COHb > 30%)

Hydrogen sulfide (Option B ruled out)

Greenish discoloration in tissues

Datura

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

Organochlorine/Kerosene (Option D ruled out)

Asphyxial signs (no specific color)

questions.text: IBD is usually associated with extraintestinal features. Which of the following hepatobiliary features is not seen in Patients with IBD?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D) Primary biliary cholangitis

Explanation:

 

Hepatobiliary disease is seen in patients with IBD as an extraintestinal feature. Primary biliary cholangitis is not seen in IBD; rather, Primary sclerosing cholangitis is seen. 

Extraintestinal manifestations of IBD:

  • Osteoporosis (M/c)
  • Helpatobiliary manifestation- Fatty liver & Primary sclerosing cholangitis (M/c with UC, p-ANCA associated)
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Rheumatological- Asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis, Sacroilitis, Ankylosing spondylitis & HLA B27+

questions.text:
Match the variants of Migraine in Column A with their characteristic clinical features in Column B:


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
			
			
			A. Associated with blindness and scintillating scotomas
			
		
		
			
			2. Cluster Headaches
			
			
			B. Retro-orbital pain in males
			
		
		
			
			3. Retinal Migraine
			
			
			C. Associated with occulomotor palsy
			
		
		
			
			4. Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
			
			
			D. Presents with hemiplegia and can be confused with stroke
			
		
		
			 
			
			E. Diagnosis often involves neuroimaging to rule out cerebrovascular accidents
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-C, 2-B, 3-A, 4-D

Explanation:

Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine can present with neurological deficits, such as third nerve palsy, which may include symptoms like ptosis and squinting.

Cluster Headaches
  • Cluster headaches are known for their unilateral, severe pain typically located around the eye, often described as retro-orbital pain.

Retinal Migraine
  • Associated with transient vision loss or blindness due to vasospasm of the retinal arteries.
  • Symptoms such as scintillating scotomas are also present.

Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
  • Rare type of migraine that includes hemiplegia (temporary paralysis on one side of the body) as a symptom.
  • Because of this, it can easily be confused with a stroke.

questions.text: Which of the following would possibly confirm the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis following an Edrophonium test?

choices.text: No change in muscle strength after administration of edrophonium
Worsening of muscle weakness after administration of edrophonium
Temporary improvement in muscle strength after administration of edrophonium
Development of severe muscle cramps after administration of edrophonium

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Temporary improvement in muscle strength after administration of edrophonium

Explanation:

The edrophonium (Tensilon) test helps differentiate between myasthenic (arising from inadequate acetylcholine at the NMJ) and cholinergic crises (resulting from excessive acetylcholine stimulation due to anticholinesterase medication overdose), which present with similar symptoms but require opposite treatments.

 

Tensilon test

  • The tensilon test involves the injection of 10 mg i.v. Edrophonium, a short-acting anticholinesterase agent.
  • Steps: 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30–60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.

Results:

  • Myasthenia Gravis: Short-lasting improvement in muscle strength.
  • Other Muscular Dystrophies: No improvement. (Option A)
  • Cholinergic crisis: No improvement or a worsening of their condition. (Option B)

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with chronic abdominal pain, bloating, and alternating diarrhea and constipation. Following a diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS), which dietary approach is considered the most effective for managing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Low FODMAP diet

Explanation:

  • A Low FODMAP diet in IBS patients involves restricting certain fermentable carbohydrates known as FODMAPs (fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols) that are poorly absorbed in the small intestine.
  • These FODMAPs can cause symptoms of IBS such as bloating, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and gas due to their fermentation by gut bacteria and osmotic effects in the intestine.

Low gluten diet (Option A): Advised in Celiac sprue.

Atkins diet (Option B) & Ketogenic diet (Option C): Followed for weight loss.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with recurrent painful swelling and discharge at the natal cleft. He has coarse hair and reports worsening after prolonged sitting. On examination, a tender fluctuant swelling with a midline pit is noted.What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Complete surgical excision of the sinus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Drainage through a midline incision

Explanation:

Drainage through a midline incision is the most appropriate initial management for an acute pilonidal abscess.

  • It involves creating a small incision to drain the abscess and clean the cavity.
  • Pilonidal sinuses are found in the natal cleft (the groove at the top of the buttocks), consisting of one or more skin openings connected to a subcutaneous track lined with granulation tissue, often containing hair.

 

Treatment Options:

  • Conservative:
    • Cleaning, hair removal, and hygiene maintenance.
    • Cauterization with silver nitrate or laser
  • Acute Abscess Treatment:
    • Drainage through a small longitudinal incision over the abscess (Option C ruled out).
  • Surgical: 
    • Laying open sinus tracks (with/without marsupialisation)
    • Complete excision (with/without primary closure)
    • Off-midline closure techniques (Limberg, Z-plasty, Karydakis procedures).
    • Bascom Procedure: Lateral incision to clean the sinus cavity, excise midline pits, and leave lateral wounds open to heal secondarily.
    • Flap Procedures: If initial treatments fail or if the sinus recurs

 Pilonidal sinus excision and repair by rhomboid flap

questions.text: A CKD patient is determined to have adynamic bone disease. Which of the following is the best explanation for this presentation?

choices.text: Excessive use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders
Less use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Excessive use of vitamin D preparations and phosphate binders:

  • Adynamic Bone Disease in CKD Characterized by low bone turnover (↓ osteoblast & osteoclast activity) and is often iatrogenic.
  • It results from over-suppression of PTH due to use of calcitriol and calcium-containing phosphate binders like calcium acetate and calcium carbonate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of recurrent renal stones is scheduled for laser-based intracorporeal lithotripsy to treat a 2 cm stone in the renal pelvis. Which of the following lasers is most commonly used for intracorporeal lithotripsy procedures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Holmium: YAG laser

Explanation:

The Holmium: YAG laser is the most commonly used laser for intracorporeal lithotripsy as it is highly effective in fragmenting stones and is widely used for treating both renal and ureteral stones.

Types of Intracorporeal Lithotripsy

Description

Laser Lithotripsy

  • Costly but safe

Electrohydraulic Lithotripsy (EHL)

  • Mainly used for bladder stones

Ultrasonic Lithotripsy
  • Not commonly used

Ballistic Lithotripsy
  • Not commonly used

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT used to minimize blood loss in myomectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) GnRH agonist given post-operatively


Explanation:

GnRH agonist is given preoperatively to reduce bleeding. It reduces tumour vascularity and reduces blood loss during the procedure.

Techniques for reducing blood loss in myomectomy:

  • Pre-operative GnRH agonist reduces bleeding.
  • Pre-operative correction of anaemia (Option A)
  • Arrange blood and FFP. Autotransfusion is also a possibility for major surgeries.
  • Intra-op methods used to stop bleeding:
    • Uterine clamp (myoma clamp)
    • Tourniquet (Option C)
    • Injection of vasopressin called Pitressin (Option D)
    • Avoid entering the uterine cavity

questions.text: A 50-year-old female is found deceased in her living room with a shotgun wound to the head. Considering the characteristics of the injury, what type of wound is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Contact shot wound

 

Explanation:

  • A contact shot wound shows a cruciate/ stellate entry wound, especially over thick bony areas like the skull, along with a muzzle impression and burning, blackening and tattooing in the surroundings.
  • Blowback phenomenon:
    • It occurs in contact gunshot wounds, particularly over thick, bony areas such as the skull.
    • It results from the high energy and expanding gases generated when a firearm is discharged at close range.
    • As the bullet penetrates the skin, the force of the gases creates a pressure wave that causes significant tissue displacement and injury.

questions.solution:

Hematological malignancies linked to radiation:

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with recurrent abdominal pain undergoes an endoscopic biopsy of the small intestine. The pathologist observes cells with prominent eosinophilic secretory granules located in the deeper parts of the intestinal crypts. These cells are known to produce substances that destroy bacteria. Which of the following cell types is the pathologist most likely observing as shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Paneth cells

Explanation:
The cells located in the deeper parts of the intestinal crypts having prominent eosinophilic secretory granules are Paneth cells, which produce lysozyme that destroys bacteria and other microorganisms in the small intestine.

Cells in Small Intestine

Cell Type

Location

Function

Characteristics

Absorptive Columnar Cells (Enterocytes) (Option A)

Luminal surface (villi)

Absorption of amino acids, carbohydrates, and lipids

- Oval nucleus in lower part

- Striated border (microvilli)

- Junctional complexes and desmosomes

Goblet Cells

Scattered among columnar cells, increasing in number towards ileum

Mucus secretion

- Expanded upper part with mucin granules

- Flattened nucleus near base

- Abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum

Undifferentiated Cells

Walls of intestinal crypts

- Proliferate and migrate to villi

- Differentiate into absorptive or goblet cells

- Columnar cells

Paneth Cells (Zymogen Cells)

Deeper parts of intestinal crypts

- Produce lysozyme (destroys bacteria)

- May produce other enzymes

- Prominent eosinophilic secretory granules

- Considerable Golgi apparatus

- Rough endoplasmic reticulum

Endocrine Cells (Argentaffin/Enterochromaffin Cells) (Option D)

Epithelial lining, most numerous near lower ends of crypts

Secrete endocrine substances

- Membrane-bound vesicles with neuroactive substances

- Granules stain with silver salts

M Cells (Option B)

Overlying Peyer's patches

- Engulf and transport microbes to basolateral surface

- Stimulate gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT)

-Antigen-presenting function

- Microfolds instead of microvilli

questions.text: All of the following can be management options for complicated cases of TTTS except?

choices.text: Laser ablation of deep arteriovenous anastomosis
Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Single fetal reduction of the recipient twin

Explanation:

Single fetal reduction is generally considered for the donor twin in the management of Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS), so as to improve the survival chances of the recipient twin.

Twin-to-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS)

Definition
  • TTTS is characterized by deep AV anastomosis between monochorionic twins.
  • More common in MCDA>MCMA

Clinical Findings
  • Donor Twin: Oligohydramnios (<2 cm), anemia, hypovolemia, hypotension, growth restriction, "stuck" appearance.
  • Recipient Twin: Polyhydramnios (>8 cm), polycythemia, hypervolemia, hypertension, larger size, risk of heart failure and hydrops fetalis.

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Ultrasound Findings: MCDA twin pregnancy, discrepant amniotic fluid volumes, size discrepancy.
  • Doppler Studies: Abnormal blood flow patterns, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the donor twin's umbilical artery.
  • Hematologic Findings: Hemoglobin difference >5 g%, estimated fetal weight discrepancy >25%.

Management

(Option A, B and D)
  • Laser Ablation
  • Amnioreduction
  • Septostomy
  • Selective Reduction of donor twin

questions.text: A 28 y/o G3P2 woman at 39 weeks with a H/O previous C-Section with spontaneous labor in the labor ward has just delivered a healthy baby girl via vaginal delivery. She has been diagnosed with severe anemia (Hb 8 gm/dL). The obstetric team is concerned about the risk of PPH. What is the next best step in her management to prevent PPH?

choices.text: Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery

Explanation:

Administration of oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery is a crucial step in the active management of the third stage of labor, which can significantly reduce the incidence of PPH. Continuing oxytocin infusion helps maintain uterine contractions and reduces blood loss after delivery.

 

PREVENTION OF PPH

Antenatal Measures

Intranatal Measures
  • Maintain hemoglobin > 10 gm/dL (Option A)
  • Screen high-risk patients and deliver in well-equipped hospitals
  • Conduct blood grouping for all women
  • Localize the placenta in women with previous cesarean delivery using USG/MRI (Option C)
  • Plan delivery of women with morbidly adherent placenta by a senior obstetrician with blood products ready
  • Active management of the third stage of labor
  • Continue oxytocin infusion for at least one hour after delivery in induced/augmented labor
  • Administer oxytocin 5 IU slow IV during cesarean section (Option B)
  • Use Carbetocin (100 μg IV over 1 min.) to prevent PPH
  • Check the uterovaginal canal for trauma after a difficult labor or instrumental delivery
  • Observe for two hours post-delivery to ensure uterus contraction before transferring to the ward
  • Prefer local or epidural anesthesia over general anesthesia in forceps, ventouse, or breech delivery
  • Allow spontaneous placental separation during cesarean section to reduce blood loss
  • Examine the placenta and membranes routinely for completeness

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations in 2015?

choices.text: End poverty in all its forms everywhere
Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education for all
Promote sustainable consumption and production patterns

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Achieve world peace and disarmament

Explanation: 

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted by the United Nations and UNDP in 2015, aim to eradicate poverty, ensure prosperity, and protect the planet by 2030. There are 17 goals:

  1. End poverty everywhere in all its forms. (Option A ruled out)

  2. Zero hunger- Achieve food security, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture.

  3. Ensure healthy lives and well-being for all ages.

  4. Provide inclusive and equitable quality education and lifelong learning opportunities. (Option B ruled out) 

  5. Achieve gender equality and empower women and girls. 

  6. Ensure access to sustainable & clean water and sanitation for all.

  7. Ensure access to affordable, clean and modern energy for all.

  8. Promote sustainable economic growth, full employment, and decent work.

  9. Build resilient infrastructure, promote sustainable industrialization, and foster innovation.

  10. Reduce inequality within and among countries.

  11. Make cities and human settlements inclusive, safe, resilient, and sustainable

  12. Ensure sustainable consumption and production patterns. (Option C ruled out) 

  13. Take urgent action to combat climate change and its impacts. 

  14. Conserve and sustainably use water bodies - oceans, seas, and marine resources. 

  15. Protect, restore, and sustainably use terrestrial ecosystems and preserve biodiversity. 

  16. Promote peaceful and inclusive societies, ensure access to justice, and build effective institutions. 

  17. Strengthen global partnerships for sustainable development.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to severe photosensitivity and recurrent skin lesions that worsen upon sun exposure. The parents are paint factory workers living in an industrial complex. The child’s urine is noted to be dark red in color. Laboratory tests confirm elevated levels of porphyrins in the blood. Which of the following statements about the diagnosis is incorrect?

choices.text: The condition can occur due to exposure to lead, leading to decreased activity of ALA synthase.
The red fluorescence of the teeth under UV light is referred to as erythrodontia, due to emission of 600 nm wavelength by porphyrin.
Porphyrin has a specific absorption band called Soret band corresponding to 400 nm.
Photosensitivity due to the accumulation of porphyrins in the skin which release superoxide radicals causing photooxidative damage.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The condition can occur due to exposure to lead, leading to decreased activity of ALA synthase.

 

Explanation:

The condition described is more likely a type of porphyria, which involves elevated porphyrins and can occur due to lead exposure. However, the enzyme ALA synthase is not affected by lead.

Lead primarily inhibits 3 enzymes of heme synthesis:

  • Ferrochelatase
  • ALA dehydratase
  • Copro-porphyrinogen oxidase

 

Option B:

  • The 4 pyrrole rings in Porphyrins are connected by methenyl bridges (double bonds) capable of absorbing light at 400 nm and emitting light at 600 nm.
  • This 600 nm wavelength appears as the red fluorescence of the teeth under UV light, which is referred to as Erythrodontia. This property of porphyrins is being used in cancer phototherapy

 

  • Since tumors often take up more porphyrins than do normal tissues, hematoporphyrin or related compounds are administered to a patient with an appropriate tumor. The tumor is then exposed to an argon laser to excite the porphyrins, producing cytotoxic effects.


 

The light absorbed by porphyrins has a specific absorption band called the Soret band (Option C), which corresponds to around 400 nm as seen on spectrometry.

 

 

Photosensitivity in porphyria is due to the accumulation of porphyrins in the skin (Option D). Porphyrins absorb light of shorter wavelengths (higher energy) and emit longer wavelengths (lower energy), which in turn releases superoxide radicals causing photooxidative damage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with cough and breathing difficulty and was diagnosed with emphysema after radiographic examination. Which of the following genetic conditions should be suspected as a possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

 

Explanation:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic condition characterised by low levels or dysfunctional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

 

Cystic fibrosis (Option A) is a genetic disorder caused by CFTR gene mutations, leading to thick mucus, chronic lung infections, and bronchiectasis.

  • While it causes obstructive lung disease, emphysema is not typical.

 

Asthma (Option B) is a chronic inflammatory condition causing reversible airway obstruction and episodic wheezing, coughing, and breathlessness.

  • It does not typically result in emphysema or structural lung damage.

 

Bronchiectasis (Option D) is a condition of permanently dilated bronchi due to chronic infections or inflammation.

  • While it causes cough and sputum production, it does not primarily lead to emphysema.

questions.text:

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal pain for the past 5 days. The child has a history of poor appetite and dark urine. On examination, he is mildly icteric, with tender hepatomegaly but no splenomegaly. His liver function tests reveal elevated ALT and AST levels, with a significant rise in total and direct bilirubin. Anti-HAV IgM is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Supportive care with hydration and monitoring

questions.solution:
Answer: C) Supportive care with hydration and monitoring

 

Explanation:

Hepatitis A is a self-limiting viral infection, especially in children. Management typically involves supportive care, including maintaining hydration and monitoring liver function.

 

Hepatitis A:

 

Etiology: Hepatitis A Virus (HAV) is an RNA virus from the Picornavirus family.

 

Epidemiology:

  • HAV is highly contagious, transmitted primarily through the fecal-oral route.
  • Incubation period: ~3 weeks.
  • Contagious (viral shedding) from late in the incubation period until about 2 weeks after the onset of jaundice.

 

Clinical Manifestations:

  • HAV causes acute hepatitis only.
  • Often anicteric in young children, but symptomatic in older adolescents, adults, and immunocompromised patients.
  • Symptoms: Acute febrile illness with abrupt onset of anorexia, nausea, malaise, vomiting, and jaundice.

Duration of illness: 7-14 days.

 

Category

Details

Diagnosis
  • Anti-HAV IgM antibodies: Detectable during symptoms and remains positive for 4-6 months.
  • Anti-HAV IgG antibodies: Provides long-term immunity and appears within 8 weeks of symptom onset.
  • Elevated levels: ALT, AST, bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, 5′-nucleotidase, γ-glutamyl transpeptidase.

Complications
  • Full recovery is typical.
  • Acute liver failure (ALF): Rare, particularly in older adolescents, adults, and immunocompromised patients.
  • Prolonged cholestatic syndrome: Leads to pruritus and fat malabsorption, resolves without long-term effects.
  • Acute Relapsing Hepatitis
  • Fulminant hepatitis (Acute Hepatitis E > A)

Treatment
  • Supportive care: Intravenous hydration, antipruritic agents, and fat-soluble vitamin supplementation for cholestatic disease.
  • Monitor for signs of ALF.

Prevention
  • Vaccine: Two inactivated vaccines, administered intramuscularly in a 2-dose schedule (second dose 6-12 months after the first). Recommended for children >12 months.
  • Isolation: Infected individuals should be isolated for 2 weeks before and 1 week after jaundice onset.
  • Hand hygiene.
  • Immunoglobulin (Ig) Prophylaxis: For preexposure and postexposure prophylaxis, especially in children <12 months, immunocompromised individuals, those with chronic liver disease, and those allergic to the vaccine.

Prognosis
  • Excellent prognosis with no long-term sequelae.

 

 

 

Start antiviral therapy (Option A): Hepatitis A virus (HAV) infection typically does not require antiviral therapy. The treatment is generally supportive as the infection is usually self-limiting.

 

Administer Hepatitis A vaccine (Option B): The vaccine is used for prevention, not for treatment of an acute infection. Since the patient already has a positive Anti-HAV IgM, indicating an acute infection, the vaccine is not appropriate in this context.

 

Admit for immediate liver biopsy (Option D): A liver biopsy is not indicated in the acute phase of Hepatitis A. The diagnosis is based on clinical presentation and serology, and a biopsy is not necessary for routine management of this infection.

questions.text:

Stromal Cells (Option D) fill up spaces between the follicles and connective tissue, capillaries, and stroma.

questions.text: A 30 y/o man presents with a nose that appears curved from the front, giving it an S-shaped appearance. He reports a history of facial trauma during childhood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Crooked nose


Explanation:

A crooked nose is characterized by a curved midline of the nasal dorsum, which may appear C-shaped or S-shaped when viewed from the front. Trauma during childhood or early life can lead to this type of nasal deformity, making it the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's presentation.

Fig: Crooked Nose

Deviated nose (Option B) involves a straight nasal midline that has shifted to one side rather than a curved or S-shaped appearance. 

Fig: Deviated Nose

 

Septal hematoma (Option C) occurs when blood collects between the cartilage and the lining of the nasal septum. This condition causes swelling inside the nose.

 

Saddle nose deformity (Option D) is characterized by a depressed nasal dorsum

questions.text: 30-year-old man presents with periorbital oedema. Urine examination shows massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. He undergoes a kidney biopsy and Congo red staining shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amyloidosis

  • Key word is congo red staining showing apple green birefringence under polarised light for diagnosis as amyloidosis. It causes damage to glomerulus and nephrotic range proteinuria

questions.text: Which of the following appropriately represents lead time in the given figure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  B) B to Y

Explanation:

 

Lead time:

  • Time gained by early detection of disease or time difference between the earliest possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis.

questions.text: You are required to disinfect a well using Horrock’s apparatus. The well has a diameter of 1.5 meters and a depth of 10 meters. Considering 2 grams of bleaching powder (calcium hypochlorite) is needed per cubic meter of water for effective disinfection, how much bleaching powder is required to disinfect this well?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 35 grams

Explanation:

1. Calculate the volume of the well:

  • Volume of a cylinder = π × (radius)² × height (or) V= π x (diameter/2)² x height
  • Radius = Diameter / 2 = 1.5 meters / 2 = 0.75 meters
  • Height = Depth of the well = 10 meters

Volume = π × (0.75 meters)² × 10 meters

→ Volume ≈ 3.14 × 0.5625 × 10

→ Volume ≈ 17.67 cubic meters

2. Calculate the amount of bleaching powder needed:

  • Bleaching powder required = Volume of the well × Amount of bleaching powder per cubic meter

⇒ 17.67 cubic meters × 2 grams per cubic meter

  • Bleaching powder required ≈ 35.33 grams

Rounding off, the required amount of bleaching powder is approximately 35 grams.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with fatigue, joint pain, and bronze skin pigmentation. Labs show a heterozygous mutation in the HFE gene. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following is the best screening test for this condition?

choices.text: Genetic testing for the HFE gene

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transferrin saturation

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis in this case is hemochromatosis.
  • Transferrin saturation (TSAT) is the best screening test for hereditary hemochromatosis.

Serum ferritin (Option A) is a protein that stores iron in the body.

  • However, while serum ferritin levels can be a useful indicator, they are not as specific as transferrin saturation (TSAT) for diagnosing hemochromatosis.

In hereditary hemochromatosis, LFTs (Option C) may show abnormalities in advanced stages of the disease when iron overload has caused liver damage (e.g., elevated alanine transaminase or AST levels).

  • However, LFTs are not specific screening tests for hemochromatosis .

Genetic testing (Option D) for mutations in the HFE gene is the definitive diagnostic test for hereditary hemochromatosis .

questions.text: Which of the following schemes is most closely related to providing unemployment relief to eligible individuals who have lost their jobs in specific circumstances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana

Explanation:

 

Scheme

Description

Key Features

Atal Beemit Vyakti Kalyan Yojana
  • Provides financial assistance to employees covered under the ESI Act, 1948, who become unemployed.
  • Offers relief payment for up to 90 days, once in a lifetime.
  • The relief payment is 50% of the employee's wages.
  • To be eligible, the insured person must have been employed for at least two years and contributed for at least 78 days.

Abhiyan Indra Dhanush

(Option C)
  • Aims to enhance hygiene and cleanliness in ESIC hospitals.
  • Implements a VIBGYOR colour-coded pattern for changing bed sheets.

MGNREGA (Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act)

(Option D)
  • Guarantees 100 days of paid work to rural households.
  • Provides wage employment to households below the poverty line who are willing to perform unskilled manual labor.
  • Employment must be provided within 15 days of application; otherwise, the individual is entitled to unemployment allowance

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient diagnosed with mild Crohn's disease affecting the ileocecal region presents to your clinic. The patient has mild symptoms with no significant systemic involvement. What is the most appropriate first-line drug to prescribe for this patient to induce remission in mild Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Budesonide

 

Explanation:

  • Budesonide is a first-line treatment for inducing remission in mild to moderate Crohn's disease, especially when the disease is localized in the ileocecal region.
  • It is a corticosteroid with a high first-pass metabolism, resulting in fewer systemic side effects than corticosteroids like prednisone.

 

Category

Mild Crohn's Disease

Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

Induction Therapy
  • First-line: Budesonide (Option D) (preferred for ileocecal disease)or aminosalicylates (e.g., mesalamine).
  • Prednisone (Option A) for those who do not respond to budesonide.
  • Alternative: Enteral nutrition.
  • First-line: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone for short term) or biologics
    Anti-TNF agents (Infliximab (Option C), Adalimumab)
  • Anti-integrin therapy (Vedolizumab)
  • Anti-interleukin therapy (Ustekinumab)
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents plus immunomodulators (Azathioprine, 6-MP) (Option B)

Maintenance Therapy
  • First-line: Continue aminosalicylates if effective.
  • Alternative: Thiopurines (azathioprine, 6-MP) for patients intolerant to aminosalicylates.
  • Anti-TNF monotherapy: Long-term for maintaining remission.
  • Combination therapy: Anti-TNF agents with immunomodulators (for severe cases or history of nonresponse to biologics).
  • Continue anti-integrin or anti-interleukin agents for those induced by these therapies

Monitoring
  • Regular follow-up to monitor symptoms and inflammation.
  • Ileocolonoscopy 6-12 months post-remission. Drug level monitoring and fecal calprotectin to assess mucosal healing.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for a routine check-up. During the visit, her diet is discussed, and it is noted that she has been consuming a high carbohydrate diet. You are asked to explain the impact of her dietary habits on glycogen metabolism. Which of the following statements best describes glycogen metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B)Reduced peripheral lipolysis

A high-carbohydrate diet increases blood glucose levels, leading to insulin secretion, which promotes glycogen synthesis and suppresses glycogen breakdown. The body enters the fed state, characterized by active glycogenesis and glucose utilization.

  • High glucose levels → Insulin release
  • Insulin stimulates glycogen synthase → Increased glycogen synthesis
  • Inhibits glycogen phosphorylase → Decreased glycogen breakdown.

Glycogen Metabolism in Different Metabolic States

Glycogen metabolism is regulated by the body's metabolic state, primarily influenced by insulin, glucagon, and epinephrine. The balance between glycogenesis (glycogen synthesis) and glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown) ensures glucose homeostasis.

Metabolic State Primary Hormone Glycogen Metabolism Key Enzymes Involved
Fed State (Option B ruled out) Insulin ↑ Glycogenesis, ↓ Glycogenolysis Glycogen synthase (activated), Glycogen phosphorylase (inhibited)
Fasted State (Option A ruled out) Glucagon ↑ Glycogenolysis, ↓ Glycogenesis Glycogen phosphorylase (activated), Glycogen synthase (inhibited)
Starvation State (Option C ruled out) Glucagon, Cortisol Glycogen nearly depleted, ↑ Gluconeogenesis Gluconeogenic enzymes (e.g., PEPCK, F-1,6-BPase)
Post-Exercise State (Option D ruled out) Epinephrine, Insulin (during recovery) ↑ Glycogenolysis during exercise, ↑ Glycogenesis during recovery Glycogen phosphorylase (exercise), Glycogen synthase (recovery)

Fed State and Glycogenesis (Option B ruled out)

  • After a high-carbohydrate meal, blood glucose levels increase, stimulating insulin secretion from the pancreas.
  • Insulin activates glycogen synthase, promoting the conversion of glucose into glycogen in the liver and muscle.
  • Glycogenolysis is inhibited to store excess glucose.

Fasted State and Glycogenolysis (Option A ruled out)

  • Low blood glucose stimulates glucagon release, which activates glycogen phosphorylase, breaking down glycogen into glucose-1-phosphate.
  • This provides energy for vital functions, primarily in the liver to maintain blood glucose levels.

Starvation State and Gluconeogenesis (Option C ruled out)

  • Glycogen stores are depleted after prolonged fasting.
  • The body shifts to gluconeogenesis, converting amino acids and glycerol into glucose.
  • Cortisol and glucagon drive this process.

Post-Exercise State and Glycogen Replenishment (Option D ruled out)

  • After intense exercise, muscle glycogen is depleted, and the body prioritizes glycogen resynthesis.
  • Insulin sensitivity is high, allowing rapid glucose uptake for glycogenesis in muscle cells.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman has been complaining of patchy scalp hair loss for the past three weeks. Her past medical history is significant for vitiligo and thyroid disorders. On examination, she has a well-circumscribed area of hair loss over her occipital region, as shown below. Which among the following is not a feature of the disease described?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Trichoclasis

 

Explanation:

This patient with a history of autoimmune diseases and patchy hair loss as described in the question and image is suggestive of alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis is a feature of a feature of trichorrhexis nodosa, not alopecia areata.

Trichoclasis:

  • It is a transverse break in the hair shaft through a node seen in Trichorrhexis nodosa.
  • It is a hair shaft disorder where the hair shaft is excessively fragile due to the presence of nodes.
  • The end of the hair resembles a small paint brush with cortical fibers extruding through the fracture as shown in the image.
  • The proximal end of the hair shaft is normal, unlike in alopecia areata.

 

  • It is associated with rare genetic diseases like argininosuccinate lyase deficiency.
  • Clinical features: Sparse, brittle, and lustreless hair
  • Diagnosis is through physical examination and hair shaft microscopy
  • Treatment includes avoiding trauma to the hair and management of the medical cause.

 

The features of alopecia areata include

  • Ophiasis is scalp hair loss in the occipital region, whereas sisaipho is the opposite of this variant, with scalp hair loss sparing the temporal and occipital areas.
Ophiasis Sisaipho


 

  • Exclamation mark hair
  • Turning grey syndrome: It is a feature of alopecia areata where white hair are typically spared by immune cells, leading to loss of black hair with sparing of white hair
  • Nail pitting: Regular, geometric pitting of the nail bed as shown below.

Note: Psoriasis shows irregular pitting.

Treatment depends on the extent of the disease. Topical therapy for limited disease is done using intralesional steroids and contact immunotherapy whereas systemic therapy, Levamisole or Cyclosporine is used for extensive disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with cough, fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. She recently cleaned an old barn where she was exposed to large amounts of bird droppings. On examination, she has mild tachycardia, and her lungs exhibit scattered crackles. A chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrates and several calcified nodules. Histopathology and a lactophenol cotton blue (LPCB) mount of cultured colonies are provided. What treatment is she started on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amphotericin-B 

 

Explanation:

  • Based on the patient’s history, histopathology showing intramacrophagic yeast form and (LPCB) mount showing numerous hyaline hyphae with few tuberculate macroconidia (arrows) and many smooth-walled oval microconidia are pointing towards a diagnosis of disseminated histoplasmosis.

Histoplasmosis

Diagnosis

Microscopy:

  • Stained smears of the specimens show small intra- and extracellular yeast cells
 

Culture:

  • Blood agar and Sabouraud agar show characteristic growth
  • White, cottony, mycelial growth with large, thick-walled, spherical spores with tuberculate (finger-like projections)
 

Serodiagnosis:

  • Antibody titers increase in progressive disease
  • Antigen tests on urine and serum are helpful for immunocompromised individuals.

Skin Test:

  • Delayed hypersensitivity to histoplasmin confirms exposure

Treatment

Amphotericin-B (Option B) for two to four weeks, followed by a year of itraconazole (Option A ruled out)

Fluconazole (Option C ruled out): It is usually reserved for less severe infections or maintenance therapy after initial treatment with more potent antifungals like amphotericin-B. 

Surgical resection (Option D ruled out): It may be considered for localised infections or complications like abscesses, but it is not appropriate as a primary treatment strategy for disseminated histoplasmosis.

questions.text: Which of the following options would be considered an indication for surgical intervention in Pott’s spine?

choices.text: Worsening neural complications despite conservative treatment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

All of them are indications for surgical intervention in cases of Pott's spine.

 

Indications for surgery in patients without neurological complications

Indications for surgery in patients with neurological complications
  • Progressive bone destruction despite ATT
  • Failure to respond to conservative therapy
  • Paravertebral abscess, when it has increased in size despite medical treatment
  • Spinal instability caused by destruction or collapse, destruction of two or more vertebrae, or kyphosis
  • Prevention of severe kyphosis in young children with extensive dorsal lesions
  • Large paraspinal abscess
  • New or worsening neural complications or lack of improvement with conservative treatment
  • Paraplegia of rapid onset or severe paraplegia
  • Late-onset paraplegia
  • Neural arch disease
  • Painful paraplegia in elderly patients
  • Spinal tumor syndrome (epidural spinal tuberculoma without osseous involvement)

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the image given?

choices.text: Can help identify the white-coat effect in patients
Continuous readings for a full 24-hour period
Measures both awake and sleep averages

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Used to investigate hypertension only

Explanation:

The image depicts Ambulatory BP Monitoring (ABPM). ABPM is used to investigate hypotensive episodes along with hypertension. These hypotensive episodes can occur due to autonomic dysfunction.

Parameter

Ambulatory BP Monitoring (ABPM)

Home Blood Pressure Monitoring (HBPM)

Device Type

Oscillometric

Oscillometric

Operation

Worn by patient, preprogrammed, fully automatic

Self-administered by the patient

Monitoring Duration

Present in report

Present in report

Self-monitoring for hypertension management

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the given drug?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Blocks Na+ channels

 

Explanation:

Image shown is Bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. All local anesthetic acts by inhibiting Na+ channels.

Mechanism of action & absorption:

  • Site: acts on nodes of ranvier
  • Blocks transmission of pain impulse from nociceptor to spinal cord.
  • Acts on intracellular side of Na channels at inactivation gate blocking the channel.
  • LA doesn’t affect RMP of nerves.
  • Blocks inactivation gates of Na+ channels → Disrupts depolarisation → No action potential generated → No pain sensation.
  • Highest systemic absorption (routes of administration): IV route >Tracheal > Intercostal > Brachial plexus > Epidural.
  • Form for onset of LA action (to reach target nerve) - Unionized form.
  • Active form at site of block of Na channels- Ionized form.
  • Higher doses will act for longer duration and lower doses for a relatively shorter duration.

 

Duration of onset for different local anesthetics (infiltration anesthesia):

Short Duration
  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine

Moderate Duration
  • Lidocaine
  • Prilocaine

Long Duration
  • Bupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine
  • Shortest acting- Chloroprocaine
  • Longest acting- Dibucaine
  • Fastest onset- Chloroprocaine (low potency so high concentration used) > Lignocaine (pka is near physiological pH)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with diplopia that develops daily in evening hours along with difficulty in swallowing. On examination left eye ptosis is noted. Ice pack test shows improvement in ptosis. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. The report of antibody panel is awaited. Which of the following will not be useful in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer-A) Physostigmine

  • This is a case of Myasthenia Gravis, as diurnal variation of neuro-symptoms is seen, and the ice pack test shows resolution of ptosis. 
  • Physostigmine crosses the blood-brain barrier and has central action. It has no role in the management of disorders of the peripheral nervous system.

Plasma exchange (Option B) & Intravenous immunoglobulins (Option D): IVIg and PLEX would be required if this patient develops Myasthenic crisis.  

Pyridostigmine (Option C): Pyridostigmine is an anticholinesterase drug that is specifically used to increase acetylcholine activity at the neuromuscular junction, making it the most appropriate treatment for this patient

questions.text: During a dermatology demonstration on the Koebner phenomenon, the professor also discusses the pseudo-Koebner phenomenon.Which of the following conditions typically shows a pseudo-Koebner response?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Warts

Explanation: Koebner phenomenon (isomorphic response): Appearance of new lesions at sites of skin trauma in diseases like psoriasis and lichen planus.
Pseudo-Koebnerization: Seen in warts (verruca vulgaris) due to autoinoculation from trauma or seeding of microorgaisms 

Types of Koebnerisation
 

Category

Cause

Examples

Images

Category 1 (True koebnerization)

Development of lesions at sites of trauma.
  • Psoriasis
  • Lichen planus (Option A)
  • Vitiligo

Psoriasis

 

Category 2 (Pseudo koebnerization)

Non-immunological and occurs due to auto-inoculation and not trauma.
  • Verruca vulgaris (warts)
  • Molluscum

Warts

 

Category 3 (Occasional koebnerization)

The phenomenon is infrequent or occurs only in specific circumstances.
  • Darier disease
  • Erythema multiforme (Option D).

Erythema multiforme

 

Category 4 (Dubious association with trauma)

Limited evidence or conflicting reports regarding the role of trauma in lesion formation.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris (Option B)
  • Lupus erythematosus

Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic liver disease is noted to have elevated blood ammonia on laboratory testing. Which of the following is least likely to result from ammonia neurotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Muscle rigidity

 

Explanation:

  • Elevated ammonia crosses the blood–brain barrier and is detoxified to glutamine in astrocytes.

    • Excess glutamine increases osmotic pressure, leading to astrocyte swelling, cerebral edema, and impaired neurotransmission.

  • Clinical features of ammonia neurotoxicity: CNS dysfunction manifests as tremors, slurred speech, drowsiness, incoordination, visual disturbances, and in severe cases, coma or death.

  • Rigidity involves extrapyramidal/motor pathways, which are not primarily affected by ammonia.

    • Muscle tone is usually preserved in hyperammonemia, helping differentiate it from conditions like Parkinsonism or tetanus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient undergoes cardiac catheterization with simultaneous ECG recording. During the isovolumic relaxation phase, which combination of events is most accurate?

choices.text: T wave ends; ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure; mitral valve opens
U wave begins; ventricular pressure equals aortic pressure; all valves closed
P wave starts; ventricular volume increases; tricuspid valve opens
Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure drops rapidly; aortic valve closes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure drops rapidly; aortic valve closes

 

Explanation :

During the isovolumic relaxation phase:

  • It starts with S2 (closure of aortic valve).

  • All valves are closed → no blood enters or leaves.

  • Ventricular pressure falls rapidly as myocardium relaxes.

  • Ventricular volume stays unchanged since valves are shut.

 

  • T wave (Option A): Ends before isovolumic relaxation. This phase ends when LV pressure falls below LA pressure → mitral valve opens → rapid filling begins.

  • U wave (Option B): Appears after T wave, before P wave. LV pressure < aortic, valves closed, but this isn’t the unique hallmark of the phase.

  • P wave (Option C): Occurs in late diastole (atrial contraction). During isovolumic relaxation, LV volume is constant and tricuspid valve stays closed.

questions.text: What is the recommended dose of adrenaline for neonatal resuscitation in a preterm baby at NICU with HR persistently below 60/min?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 0.02mg/kg/dose

 

Explanation:

  • Dose of Inj.Adrenaline: 0.02mg/kg/dose or 0.2ml/kg/dose given in 1:10000 dilution up to three times in neonatal resuscitation
  • The preferred route of administration: IV through umbilical venous catheterization. It can be given intratracheally if IV access is not available.
  • Indications: Use of adrenaline is indicated if HR remains below 60/min despite adequate ventilation and chest compression for 30 seconds.
