questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with a non-healing ulcer on his left leg and hand. He gives a history of frequently swimming in a local pool. The ulcer grew in size gradually and developed into a chronic, painless granuloma as shown in the image. Which organism is most likely responsible for his condition?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Mycobacterium marinum

 

Explanation:

M. marinum is a photochromogen associated with "swimming pool granuloma," resulting from exposure to contaminated water. The chronic, painless ulcer described depicts the case of an M. marinum infection.

 

Runyon Classification of NTM

Group

Characteristics

Examples

Group I: Photochromogens

Produce pigment in light; slow growth.
  • M. kansasii (lung disease), (Option A ruled out)
  • M. marinum ("swimming pool granuloma"). (Option B)

Group II: Scotochromogens

Produce pigment regardless of light; varied growth rates.
  • M. scrofulaceum (swollen lymph nodes),
  • M. gordonae (water contamination).

Group III: Non-photochromogens

No pigment production; diverse characteristics.
  • M. avium complex (lung infections), (Option C ruled out)
  • M. ulcerans (Buruli ulcers).

Group IV: Rapid Growers

Grow quickly; early colony formation.
  • M. fortuitum (skin abscesses), (Option D ruled out)
  • M. chelonae (injection site infections).

.

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and occasional hemoptysis. A chest radiograph of the patient is given. Which investigation would be most appropriate for confirming the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chest computed tomography (CT)

Explanation:

  • The clinical features and the presence of a “tram track sign” on the chest radiograph point to a diagnosis of Bronchiectasis.
  • Chest computed tomography (CT) is the imaging technique of choice for confirming bronchiectasis. 

 

Chest CT findings of bronchiectasis include:

  1. Airway dilation (detected as parallel “tram tracks” or cross-sectional area showing signet-ring sign).
  2. Lack of bronchial tapering
  3. Bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways
  4. Inspissated secretions (e.g., the “tree-in-bud” pattern)
  5. Cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis).

 

Bronchiectasis - Tram track sign

X-ray

HRCT
 

Black arrows pointing to the tram track sign
 

Red arrows pointing to the tram track sign

 

 

Sputum analysis (Option A): Although sputum analysis can help identify specific pathogens responsible for infections in bronchiectasis, it does not establish the diagnosis of bronchiectasis itself.

 

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) (Option C): PFTs are important for evaluating overall lung function; however, it is not specific to diagnosing bronchiectasis.

 

Bronchoscopy (Option D): Bronchoscopy can be useful for identifying obstructions or taking biopsies, however it is not the primary investigation for diagnosing bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding Work Sampling as a health management technique?

choices.text: Work Sampling involves systematic observation and recording of activities at random intervals to estimate the proportion of time spent on different tasks.
Work Sampling is used for the evaluation of Doctors, Nurses, and Pharmacists.
Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.
Work Sampling is a quantitative type of health management technique.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Work Sampling helps to calculate the total project cost by evaluating the monetary benefits of health interventions.

Explanation:
Work Sampling does not involve calculating project costs or evaluating monetary benefits.

  • It is primarily used to systematically observe and record the activities of individuals at random intervals to estimate how time is allocated among various tasks, aiding in workforce management and efficiency improvement. (Option A)
  • It is used to evaluate how time is spent by healthcare providers like doctors, nurses, and pharmacists on different activities. (Option B)
  • It is a type of quantitative health management technique. (Option D)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a laceration to his right wrist after a slash injury. On examination, there is weakness of thumb opposition and numbness over the thenar eminence. Which structure is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Median nerve

 

Explanation:

The median nerve passes through the carpal tunnel and is most commonly affected in the slash injuries that cut across the palmar side.

  • Wrist slash injuries commonly occur due to suicide cuts at wrist and can lead to: 
    • Loss of sensation in the thenar eminence
    • Loss of sensation in the lateral 3 and half digits on palmar side
    • Motor loss of LOAF muscles
    • Atrophy of thenar eminence
    • Ape thumb deformity

Wrist Slash Injuries

Nerves affected
  • Median nerve
  • Ulnar nerve (less common): Innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand (like the hypothenar muscles and lumbricals for the ring and little fingers), and it also provides sensory innervation to the little finger and half of the ring finger. (Option C)

Arteries affected
  • Radial artery
  • Ulnar artery


Flexor carpi radialis (Option A) is a muscle of the anterior forearm that primarily contributes to wrist flexion and abduction but it does not affect thumb opposition or sensation in the thenar eminence.

 

 

Radial nerve (Option B) provides motor innervation to the extensor muscles of the forearm and sensory innervation to the dorsal side of the hand but it does not involve in the thumb opposition, and numbness in the thenar eminence.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of painless swelling in her external genitalia. On examination of the vulva, a tense, fluctuant mass is palpable at the posterior vaginal introitus, measuring approximately 3 cm in diameter (as shown below). No signs of inflammation are present. Which of the following is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Hot compress over the area and analgesics

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Marsupialization

Explanation:
Marsupialization is the most effective surgical treatment for Bartholin's cysts. It involves creating a permanent opening for drainage by suturing the cyst lining to the vaginal mucosa.

Bartholin’s Cyst

  • Bartholin's cyst forms when the duct or gland becomes obstructed, leading to fluid buildup.
    • Differential diagnosis:
      • Gartner duct cyst or GDC (located on the lateral or anterior wall)
      • Skene gland cyst (lateral to urethral meatus)
  • The cyst usually contains a clear, non-tender fluid—a product of the Bartholin's gland's secretion.
  • A physical examination typically reveals a soft, fluctuant swelling in the posterior part of the labia majora, often making the vulvar cleft appear S-shaped (a normal Bartholin's gland is not palpable during a physical examination)
  • They are managed by marsupialisation (recurrence on simple aspiration), followed by antibiotics.

Tetracycline suspecting chlamydial infection (Option A) and Ampicillin 500 mg 8 hourly (Option B) are both management of Bartholin’s abscess.

Hot compress over the area and analgesics (Option C): Hot compress over the area does reduce the size of the cyst and analgesics have no application as Bartholin cyst is a painless swelling.

questions.text:
50-year-old female with Type 2 diabetes mellitus comes for consultation due to extreme fatigue and thirst. BP 170/100 mm Hg . She is non compliant on her medicines and latest labs are mentioned below. Which is not correct about management of this case? 


	Random Plasma Glucose: 286 mg/dl
	HbA1c: 11.2 %
	Urine glucose +++
	Serum creatinine 2 mg/dl 
	eGFR: 25 mL/min
	Serum potassium 6.5 meq /dl
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Start Metformin with Sitagliptin

The patient has developed diabetic nephropathy and eGFR of 25 implies grade 4 CKD. 

Metformin is contraindicated in patients with significant renal impairment (eGFR < 30 mL/min) due to the increased risk of lactic acidosis.Sitagliptin is metabolized by kidney. Control of hyperrtension with CCB is required as serum potassium is elevated. ACEi are not be given with high potassium values. Empagliflozin is indicated as eGFR is less than 30 ml /min and it shows cardio renal benefit by lowering SBP.

Explanation:

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female died within a few months after being diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The autopsy revealed a yellowish, spherical neoplasm in one pole of the kidney. The tumour cells invaded the renal vein and inferior vena cava. Histopathology is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

 


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Clear cell RCC

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the histopathology image is suggestive of Clear cell carcinoma

Clear cell carcinoma:

  • Classical clearing of cells is due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids.
  • It is a yellowish neoplasm due to prominent lipid accumulation.
  • It is the most common renal cell carcinoma and is associated with the deletion of chromosome 3p which leads to Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with high fever, diffuse macular rash, hypotension, purulent vaginal discharge, and desquamation of the skin on her palms and soles. She has used tampons during her recent menstrual cycle and forgot to remove them on time. Laboratory tests reveal a Gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus. Which toxin is primarily responsible for the condition observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Toxic shock syndrome toxin

 

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the woman is suffering from Toxic shock syndrome due to tampon use, which is often associated with Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Bacteria produce Toxic shock syndrome toxin, a superantigen that can trigger a massive immune response causing high fever, rash, hypotension, and desquamation.


 

Disease caused by staphylococcus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin (Option B)

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option D)


Beta-hemolysin is not responsible for Toxic shock syndrome (Option C)

questions.text: RAIU scan was performed for a 35 year old lady with hypertension and palpitations. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Graves' disease 

In Graves' disease, there is diffusely increased uptake of radioactive iodine throughout an enlarged gland, often described as a "hot" appearance.

 

Thyroid scan:

  • Thyroid scans use radioactive iodine (I-123) or technetium-99m to assess thyroid function and structure on RAIU scans.
  • Increased uptake indicates hyperfunction, while decreased uptake suggests hypofunction or thyroiditis.
  • The pattern of uptake helps differentiate between diffuse (Graves') and nodular (toxic adenoma, multinodular) causes of hyperthyroidism.
  • Thyroid scans are useful when TSH is suppressed to determine the cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal Thyroid: Uniform uptake throughout the gland.
  • Graves' Disease: Diffusely increased uptake throughout an enlarged gland.
  • Toxic Multinodular Goiter: Multiple areas of increased and decreased uptake. (Option A)
  • Toxic Adenoma: Single area of increased uptake with suppression of surrounding tissue. (Option D)
  • Thyroiditis: Very low or no uptake due to inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue. (Option C)
  • Thyroid Cancer: Usually appears as "cold" nodules (areas of decreased uptake).

questions.text:
Match the following: 


	
		
			1)
			
			a) FLAIR
		
		
			2)
			
			b) Diffusion-weighted MRI
		
		
			3)
			
			
			c) T1-Weighted MRI
			
		
		
			4)
			
			d) T2-Weighted MRI
questions.solution:
Tissue

T1-Weighted

T2-Weighted

FLAIR

Dark

Bright

Dark

White matter

Light

Dark gray

Cortex

(Gray matter)

Gray

Light gray

Light gray

Fat

Bright

Light

Light

Inflammation

Dark

Bright

Bright

DWI (Diffuse Weighted Imaging):

  • Measures diffusion of water molecules & is sensitive to changes in cellular density.
  • Lacks the outline of the skull and scalp, focusing primarily on brain tissue.
  • Acute ischemic strokes and high cellularity areas, such as tumours, both appear hyperintense (bright) due to restricted water diffusion.

FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) nullifies the CSF signals & enhances the visibility of lesions, edema, and infarcts.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with a history of abdominal surgery performed 3 days ago. She reports worsening abdominal distension and has not passed stool since the surgery. On examination her abdomen is distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) X-ray shows dilated bowel loops and air-fluid levels 

Explanation:

This presentation is consistent with Paralytic Ileus, a condition where impaired peristaltic activity results in decreased bowel motility.

  • Characterized by:
    • Impaired intestinal motility due to failure of peristaltic wave transmission.
    • Collection of food and fluid in the bowel (Option A).
    • Abdominal distension.

Etiology
  • Abdominal surgery.
  • Uremia.
  • Mesenteric ischemia.
  • Retroperitoneal hematoma.
  • Intra-abdominal sepsis.
  • Dyselectrolytemia (e.g., hypokalemia) (Option D ruled out).
  • Drugs affecting intestinal motility:
    • Opiates.
    • Antipsychotics.

Investigations

IOC: Abdominal X-ray. (Option C ruled out)

Findings:

  • Dilated bowel loops.
  • Gas in the colon and rectum.
  • Multiple air-fluid levels.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency room after ingesting kidney-shaped seeds while camping. Upon examination, he exhibits dry mouth, dilated pupils, blurred vision, flushed skin, tachycardia, hallucinations, agitation, and disorientation. What is the most appropriate antidote for this poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Physostigmine

Explanation:

The patient's symptoms suggest anticholinergic toxicity, likely due to the ingestion of Datura seeds. Physostigmine 1mg IV (hourly) is used as an antidote for datura poisoning.

 

Toxins and Antidotes

Toxicity

Antidote

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine (Option B)

Opium

Naloxone (Option A ruled out)

Organophosphates

  • Atropine
  • Pralidoxime

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Methanol

Fomepizole (Option D ruled out)

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Cyanide

Eli Lilly Antidote Kit (3-step approach)

Pyridostigmine (Option C) also inhibits acetylcholinesterase; it does not penetrate the blood-brain barrier, making it less suitable for addressing the central nervous system effects of anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Route 
			
			
			Percentage Bioavailability
			
		
		
			
			1) 

			
			
			
			a) 100

			4)

			 

			           
			
			
			d) 5-100
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Bioavailability:

  • It measures the fraction (F) of the administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in an unchanged form.
  • Bioavailability of a drug injected i.v. is 100%, but is frequently lower after oral ingestion because:
    • The drug may be incompletely absorbed.
    • The absorbed drug may undergo first-pass metabolism in the intestinal wall/liver or be excreted in bile.

Route of Administration

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the nature of vegetation in infective endocarditis (IE)?

choices.text: Typically contain only fibrin and inflammatory cells
Most commonly found on the tricuspid valve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prone to embolisation

Explanation:

  • Vegetation in infective endocarditis is large and bulky, typically composed of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells (Option B)

  • Embolization: Due to bulkiness, parts of the vegetation can break off, and these detached fragments are called emboli, which can travel through the bloodstream, causing systemic embolization. 

  • Embolization is common but not guaranteed.

Smooth and non-destructive lesions (Option A): Seen in non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), not in infective endocarditis.

Contain only fibrin and inflammatory cells (Option B): IE vegetations also include microorganisms and platelets.

Most commonly found on the tricuspid valve (Option D): True mainly in IV drug users; overall, the mitral valve is the most commonly affected.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the nose are true?

 


	The anterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the nasal bones.
	The floor of the nose is formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone.
	The posterior sloping part of the roof of the nose is formed by the body of the sphenoid bone.
	The anterior three-fourths of the floor of the nose is formed by the palatine process of the maxilla.
	The posterior one-fourth of the floor of the nose is formed by the horizontal part of the sphenoid bone.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

Each nasal cavity features a lateral wall, a medial wall, a roof, and a floor.

 

Roof of the nose

Floor of the nose
  • Anterior Sloping Part: Formed by the nasal bones. (Statement 1)
  • Posterior Sloping Part: Formed by the body of the sphenoid bone. (Statement 3)
  • Middle Horizontal Part: Formed by the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (passage of olfactory nerves into the nasal cavity). (Statement 2)
  • Anterior Three-Fourths: Formed by the palatine process of the maxilla. (Statement 4)
  • Posterior One-Fourth: Formed by the horizontal part of the palatine bone. (Statement 5)

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents with right-sided hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus with fast phase to the right. The nystagmus worsens in darkness and improves with fixation. There is no nausea or vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Central vestibular nystagmus due to a cerebellar lesion
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis
Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis
Central vestibular nystagmus due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis

 

Explanation:

The patient’s horizontal nystagmus, with a fast phase to the right, worsens in darkness and improves with fixation, which suggests peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis.

Feature

Peripheral Nystagmus

Central Nystagmus

Location of lesion

Labyrinth or vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve

Central neural pathways (vestibular nuclei, brainstem, cerebellum)

Latency

2-20 seconds

No latency

Duration

Less than 1 minute

More than 1 minute

Type of Nystagmus

Spontaneous nystagmus

Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus

Direction of Nystagmus

Fixed, towards the undermost ear

Change with direction of gaze

Fatigability

Fatigable

Non-fatigable

Response to Visual Fixation

Suppressed by Optic fixation; Worsens in darkness or with Frenzel glasses (+20 dioptre glasses), both abolishing optic fixation

Cannot be suppressed

Accompanying Symptoms
  • Severe vertigo
  • Loss of hearing in one ear
  • Ringing in one or both ears
  • Difficulty focusing vision
  • Loss of balance

None or slight:

  • Impairment in speech
  • Weakness or numbness
  • Gait disturbance
  • Impairment in vision

 

In Purulent Labyrinthitis (Option C), Vertigo is due to the inner ear bacterial infection, with total loss of cochlear and vestibular functions. Nystagmus would be on the opposite side, and there would be severe nausea and vomiting.

 

Central Vestibular Nystagmus (Option A and D) does not improve with optic fixation and has changing directions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric clinic after a heart murmur was detected during a recent febrile illness. On examination, the child has a soft ejection systolic murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border. The second heart sound (S2) is normal. The child is asymptomatic, with no history of cyanosis, syncope, or respiratory distress. The fever has resolved, and the child is otherwise well. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Reassure the parents that the murmur is likely innocent, and no further follow-up is necessary.
Immediately order an ECG and echocardiogram to rule out congenital heart disease.
Reassure the parents and schedule a follow-up assessment in a few weeks to reassess the murmur.
Refer to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation without additional tests.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reassure the parents and schedule a follow-up assessment in a few weeks to reassess the murmur.

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the murmur is soft, systolic, and accompanied by a normal second heart sound, which is characteristic of an innocent murmur.
  • Since the murmur was detected during a febrile illness, it is likely to disappear as the illness resolves.
  • The best approach is to reassure the parents and plan a follow-up assessment to ensure the murmur has resolved, rather than immediately pursuing diagnostic tests or specialist referral.

 

Nada’s criteria: (used for clinical diagnosis of congenital heart disease)

 

Major

Minor

Systolic murmur grade III or more

Systolic murmur grade I or II

Diastolic murmur

Abnormal second heart sound

Cyanosis

Abnormal ECG

Congestive cardiac failure

Abnormal X-ray
 

Abnormal Blood pressure

 

Presence of one major or 2 minor criteria is needed to indicate the presence of CHD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is undergoing a gynecological procedure in the lithotomy position. The surgeon is identifying the bony landmarks for access to the pelvic organs. During the examination, the surgeon palpates a bony structure near the midline at the anterior aspect of the perineum. Which of the following bony landmarks is the surgeon most likely palpating?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pubic symphysis

 

Explanation:

Pubic symphysis is located at the anterior aspect of the perineum and is easily palpated when the patient is in the lithotomy position.

 

View from Lithotomy Position:

Bones and Anatomical Landmarks:

  • Pubic Symphysis: Located at the anterior aspect of the pelvis and acts as the anterior boundary of the perineum. 
  • Ischiopubic Rami: They form the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle and are important as attachment points for muscles like the ischiocavernosus and the deep and superficial perineal muscles.
  • Ischial Tuberosities: They serve as the lateral borders of the anal triangle. In the lithotomy position, the ischial tuberosities can be palpated as they provide attachment points for the superficial transverse perineal muscles and are important in identifying the perineal body. 
  • Coccyx: The small, triangular bone at the base of the spine, forming the posterior border of the pelvic outlet and provides an attachment point for the coccygeus muscle.
  • Sacrum: Lies posteriorly and superiorly, forming the posterior wall of the pelvic cavity.
  • Obturator Foramen: A large opening formed by the pubis and ischium which allows the passage of the obturator nerve and vessels.

 

Perineal Regions Related to Bones: From the lithotomy position, the perineal area can be divided into the urogenital triangle and the anal triangle.


 

Muscles Attached to Bony Landmarks (Visible from Lithotomy Position):

  • Levator Ani (Pubococcygeus, Iliococcygeus): Support the pelvic organs and form part of the pelvic diaphragm.
  • Ischiocavernosus and Bulbospongiosus: Attach to the ischiopubic rami and help in erection (males) and clitoral function (females).
  • Superficial and Deep Transverse Perineal Muscles: Attach to the ischial tuberosities and the perineal body, providing support to the pelvic floor.

questions.text: The logo below represents which of the following health programs?

choices.text: National program for control of blindness and visual impairment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) NLEP
Explanation:
This is the logo for the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP)

Vision: The NLEP aims for a "Leprosy-free India."

Objectives:

  1. Decrease prevalence rates to <1/10,000 at sub-national and district levels.
  2. Lower Grade II disability incidence to <1% among new cases nationally.
  3. Reduce Grade II disability cases to <1 per million population nationally.
  4. Ensure zero disabilities among new child cases.
  5. Eliminate stigma and discrimination against leprosy-affected individuals.

 

Anemia Mukt Bharat logo (Option A)

Aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia among various groups such as children, adolescent girls, pregnant women, lactating women, and women of reproductive age.

National program for control of Blindness (Option B)

To provide eye health for all and avoid blindness by identifying and treating curable causes.

Diseases covered under NPCB:

  • Trachoma
  • Cataract
  • Glaucoma
  • Childhood blindness
  • Corneal blindness
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Refractive errors and low vision

National health mission (Option C)

Aims to provide universal access to quality healthcare services through national rural health mission and national urban health mission.

questions.text: A group of 4 experts on cardiac health were invited to interact with an audience of about 100 members. However, they were not given any set agenda to speak upon nor did they have any set speeches. They are allowed to discuss among themselves during the event as well and there is no set order of speaking. What kind of event were they invited to?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Panel discussion

 

Explanation:

  • In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 persons who are qualified to talk/ discuss the topic sit and discuss a given problem or topic in front of a large group or audience, without a set agenda or order of speaking and with audience interaction at the end of the discussion.
  • Symposium: In contrast to a panel discussion, a symposium involves 4-8 experts talking on a given topic with set agendas, speeches, and an order of speaking. .(Option B)

Panel discussion

Symposium

4-8 experts

4-8 experts

Two-way or Socratic

Two-way or Socratic

No set agenda

Set agenda

Not set speeches

Set speeches

No set order of speaking

Set order of speaking

Audience is present

Audience is present

Experts can discuss among themselves (they can intervene in between)

Experts cannot intervene in between (they cannot discuss among themselves)

Feedback can be taken

Feedback can be taken

Workshop (Option C):

  • A workshop is a practical educational experience in which participants learn new skills or techniques over a series of four or more meetings.

Seminar (Option D):

  • A seminar is a lecture-style presentation where a speaker provides information on a particular subject and the audience is allowed to ask questions and participate in a discussion.
  • It has a set agenda and speech.

questions.text: Which muscle is the first to regain function after muscle relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Diaphragm

Explanation:

The diaphragm, a central muscle involved in breathing, receives a high blood supply, making it one of the first to recover after muscle relaxants wear off. The fast recovery of the diaphragm is important for restoring normal respiratory function following surgery.

 

Triceps (Option A): The triceps, located in the upper arm, are peripherally situated and recover later than centrally located muscles. The slower return of function in muscles like the triceps is due to their lower blood supply and distant location from central circulation.

Adductor pollicis (Option B): Located in the hand, this peripheral muscle tends to recover more slowly because it has lower blood flow compared to central muscles. It is useful for monitoring complete neuromuscular recovery.

Quadriceps (Option C): Quadriceps exhibit a slower recovery because they are more distant from central circulation and have less blood flow compared to muscles like the diaphragm.

questions.text: A pathologist is reviewing the chromosomal locations of blood group antigens. When considering the Rh blood group system, including the Rh antigen, which of the following chromosomes is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Chr.1

 

Explanation :

  • The Rh antigen is denoted by the C, D, and E antigens, and these are located on chromosome 1 (Option A).

  • The ABO antigens are present on chromosome 9. (Option B)

  • All antigens and all blood groups are derived from a common precursor - H antigen or H substance, which is present on chromosome 19. (Option C)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a previous lower-segment cesarean section is in labor at 39 weeks of gestation and wants to attempt a trial of labor. Which of the following factors is not a benefit of the trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) as compared to elective repeat Cesarean section?

choices.text: Reduced need for future cesarean deliveries.
Reduced risk of uterine wound dehiscence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Reduced risk of uterine wound dehiscence.

 

Explanation:

Maternal Uterine wound dehiscence is a risk of TOLAC 

Vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC)

  • Described as vaginal delivery in a woman who has given birth via cesarean section in a former pregnancy.
  • Patients desiring VBAC delivery undergo a trial of labor (TOL), also called the trial of labor after cesarean section (TOLAC).

Selection Criteria of Cases for TOLAC (ACOG)
  • One (RCOG) or two (ACOG) previous lower segment transverse scar.
  • Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section.
  • Pelvis adequate for the fetus.
  • Continued labor monitoring possible.
  • Availability of resources (anesthesia, blood transfusion and theatre) for an emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes of the decision.
  • Informed consent of the woman.

 

Contraindications for TOLAC (indications for Cesarean Delivery)
  • Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision , myomectomy scar
  • Previously >2 LSCS
  • Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD.
  • Presence of other complications in pregnancy: Obstetric (pre-eclampsia, malpresentation, placenta previa) or medical.
  • Resources limited for emergency cesarean delivery or patient refusal for TOLAC.
  • History of prior uterine rupture

 

Benefits of TOLAC

Complications of Unsuccessful TOLAC
  • Decreased maternal morbidity (infection and others).
  • Reduced length of hospital stay. (Option D)
  • Decreased need for blood transfusion.
  • Decreased risk of abnormal placentation (Option A) and need for successive cesarean delivery in next pregnancy. (Option B)
  • Maternal Uterine wound dehiscence. (Option C)
  • Uterine rupture (0.5-1%).
  • Increased blood transfusion.
  • Increased risks of hysterectomy due to uterine rupture.
  • Infections increased maternal morbidity.
  • Perinatal: Low Apgar score, admission to NICU, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), neonatal death, rarely stillbirth.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of primary chronic mitral regurgitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ischemic cardiomyopathy

Explanation: 

Primary chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) refers to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve itself. Ischemic cardiomyopathy causes secondary (functional) mitral regurgitation due to left ventricular dilation or dysfunction, not a primary structural issue of the valve.

questions.text: A patient is sedated using methohexital for surgery. What is false about methohexital?

choices.text: It belongs to the barbiturates group of drugs
Acts by binding to GABA (A) receptors
Can be used to briefly control grand-mal seizures

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Produces muscle relaxation and analgesia

Explanation:
Methohexital, which is a barbiturate, does not cause muscle relaxation and does not affect pain perception. It also causes involuntary skeletal muscle contractions.

Methohexital

  • Type: A short-acting barbiturate used for induction of anesthesia. (Option A)
  • Use: commonly administered for procedural sedation and electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

Mechanism of Action

  • GABA(A) Receptor (Option B): Binds to GABA(A) receptors, enhancing GABA’s effects by increasing the duration of chloride-specific ion channel opening.
  • CNS Effects: Depresses the reticular activating system, leading to decreased consciousness.

Pharmacokinetics

  • Absorption: typically administered intravenously; can also be given rectally in children.
  • Distribution: rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier due to high lipid solubility; effects seen within 30 seconds.
  • Redistribution: duration of action is primarily determined by redistribution rather than metabolism; typically, plasma levels drop to 10% of peak within 20-30 minutes.
  • Biotransformation: primarily metabolized by the liver to inactive, water-soluble metabolites; clears faster than thiopental.
  • Excretion: excreted mainly in feces; renal excretion is limited.

Clinical Effects

  • CNS depression: induces sedation to unconsciousness based on dosage; can briefly control grand mal seizures (50-100 mg IV). (Option C)
  • Taste sensation: some patients report a garlic or onion-like taste during induction.
  • No pain impairment: does not impair pain perception.
  • Does not cause muscle relaxation but may cause involuntary muscle contractions.

Effects on Organ Systems

  • Cardiovascular: can cause hypotension and tachycardia; effects vary based on administration rate and patient condition.
  • Respiratory: may depress respiratory function; apnea can occur following induction.
  • Cerebral: reduces cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure; decreases oxygen consumption.
  • Renal: renal blood flow and GFR are reduced.
  • Hepatic: hepatic blood flow is reduced

Drug Interactions

  • CNS Depressants: effects potentiated by ethanol, opioids, and antihistamines.
  • Protein Binding: drugs that occupy protein-binding sites can displace methohexital, increasing free drug levels.

Considerations

  • Dosing: requires careful dosing, particularly in older patients or those with compromised cardiovascular status.
  • Adverse Reactions: sulfonamides reduce the effect of barbiturates, ethanol, opioids, antihistamines and other CNS depressants increase the sedative effect of barbiturates.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the test shown in the image, which is done prior to arterial blood sampling is not true?

choices.text: Preferred site for arterial sampling is the radial artery between the flexor carpi radialis tendon and the styloid process
Both ulnar and radial arteries should be released simultaneously after occlusion
The presence of collaterals is confirmed if the hand becomes flushed after releasing one artery
Pressure should be applied to the site for 5 minutes after blood sampling to prevent hematoma

questions.solution:
Simultaneous release of vessels after occlusion in Modified Allen’s test is not the appropriate technique collateral circulation cannot evaluated if both arteries are released together.

Modified Allen Test

Anatomy

• Radial artery: Lateral forearm

• Ulnar artery: Medial forearm

• Deep arch: Mainly from radial artery

• Superficial arch: Mainly from ulnar artery

Preferred Site for arterial sampling

Radial artery between flexor carpi radialis tendon and styloid process (Option A)

Indications

• Before radial artery cannulation

• Prior to arterial line placement

• Before cardiac catheterization

• Pre-radial forearm flap harvest

• Before arterial blood gas sampling

Technique
  • Sequential release allows assessment of individual collateral flow
  • Cannot evaluate collateral circulation if both are released together (Option B)
  • Examines one hand at a time
  • Avoid elbow overextension
  • Palm should initially blanch
  • Normal color should return quickly

Interpretation

Positive Test: (Option C)

• Color returns within 10 seconds → Adequate collateral flow

 

Negative Test:

• Persistent pallor after release → inadequate collateral flow →May need additional testing

• Consider temperature effects

Precaution

Pressure applied on blood sampling site for 5 minutes after sampling is done (Option D) to prevent hematoma

questions.text: A 35-year-old male marathon runner presents with complaints of foot pain after long-distance runs. On examination, the foot shows a well-formed arch, and palpation reveals tenderness along the medial aspect of the foot. An X-ray confirms a normal medial longitudinal arch structure. Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the function or anatomy of the medial longitudinal arch in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Has limited mobility

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of the medial arch
  • The medial longitudinal arch is higher and more mobile than the lateral arch, acting as a shock absorber during gait.
  • Its keystone is the head of the talus, and its main joint is the talocalcaneonavicular joint.

Takeaway:
Medial arch = high, mobile, shock absorber, talus as keystone.
Lateral arch = low, rigid, weight transmission.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with irregular menstrual cycles, acne, and hirsutism. An ultrasound reveals multiple ovarian cysts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)

Explanation:

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) diagnosis - Rotterdam criteria:
Any 2 of 3 (after excluding other causes):

1. Oligo-/anovulation

2. Hyperandrogenism (clinical/biochemical)

3. Polycystic ovaries on USG

Supporting findings: ↑ LH/FSH ratio (>2), insulin resistance (acanthosis nigricans).

 

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance


Endometriosis (Option B): Chronic pelvic pain + dysmenorrhea, no hyperandrogenism

Hypothyroidism (Option C) : Weight gain + menorrhagia + lethargy

Hyperprolactinemia (Option D): Galactorrhea + amenorrhea

questions.text: For a patient of acute onset hypernatremia Na= 158 meq/L with confusion and seizures, which of the following fluids is not to be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Normal saline:

  • The preferred fluid for symptomatic hypernatremia the fluid of choice is 5 percent dextrose. N/2 or N/4 is dilute fluid containing more water and can be used.

questions.text: A forensic team is called to investigate a case of judicial hanging in an obese individual. The victim was found suspended from a significant height with the knot positioned at the back of the neck. During the autopsy, a transverse tear in the carotid artery is observed, consistent with a long drop hanging. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Amussat's Sign

Explanation:

The scenario describes the typical presentation of Amussat's Sign, which is characterized by transverse carotid artery tears, particularly in cases of long drop hangings with posteriorly placed knots, especially in obese victims.

 

  • While dribbling of saliva (Option A ruled out) and ligature marks (Option B ruled out) are significant, Amussat's Sign specifically indicates carotid artery injuries in hanging.
  • Simon's Sign indicates hemorrhages in the lumbar spine but is not directly linked to the mechanics of hanging. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with neck pain, fever, and fatigue. His physical examination shows a tender, swollen thyroid gland. Lab reports revealed elevated inflammatory markers and low radioactive iodine uptake, and he is HLA B35 positive. What is the most appropriate initial treatment step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) NSAIDs

 

Explanation: The clinical presentation and diagnostic findings strongly indicate De Quervain’s thyroiditis (subacute or granulomatous thyroiditis), in which NSAIDs are used as first-line treatment.

 

De Quervain’s Thyroiditis/Viral thyroiditis/ Granulomatous thyroiditis:

  • Often follows a viral upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Initial Brief Hyperthyroidism due to follicular destruction followed by Hypothyroidism, which returns to an Euthyroid state in a few months. (Self Limiting)
  • Associated with HLA B35
  • IOC: FNAC
  • Clinical Features:
    • Neck Pain and Tenderness.
    • Symptoms of Hyperthyroidism and Hypothyroidism depend upon stage.
  • Diagnosis: 
    • Raised inflammatory markers
    • Radioiodine uptake low: Due to follicle destruction.
  • Management: Self Limiting Condition
    • NSAIDs: First-line treatment to control pain and inflammation.
    • Steroids: Used if NSAIDs are ineffective
    • Levothyroxine: Given only during the Hypothyroid phase (Option B is ruled out)

questions.text: A multigravida G2P1L1 delivers a baby at 37 weeks of gestation by cesarean section. On assessment, the baby was completely cyanosed having slow and irregular breathing with a heart rate of 76 bpm, and he was showing slight flexion on stimulation along with a slight frown when stimulated by an orogastric tube. Calculate the APGAR score for the baby.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4

 

Explanation: Completely cyanosed -0, slow and irregular breathing-1, HR of 76 bpm-1, slight flexion-1, slight frown-1 =4

APGAR score

  • The APGAR score is an objective method of evaluating the newborn’s condition.
  • It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.
  • Resuscitation must be initiated before the 1 minute score is assigned, therefore, it is not used to guide the resuscitation.
  • The components, along with scores, are,
 

0

1

2

Appearance

Completely blue or pale

The body is pink, and the extremities are blue

Completely pink

Pulse rate

Absent

<100/min

>100/min

Grimace

No response

Grimaces only

Coughs/sneezes

Activity

Limp and flaccid

Some flexion present

Flexed posture and actively moving limbs

Respiratory effort

None

Slow and irregular

Normal/strong

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal APGAR score is ≥7
  • Maximum score = 10; Minimum score = 0
  • Score for severe birth asphyxia = 0 - 3

 

Therefore, the APGAR score for the above case is 4. This indicates moderate distress at birth.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps in the correct order as they occur in the process of drug development:


	Filing of an Investigational New Drug (IND) application.
	Start toxicity and safety testing based on GLP guidelines.
	Approval from Central Drugs Standard Control Organization (CDSCO).
	Start pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics testing based on GCP guidelines.
	Filing of an NDA application to CDSCO.
	Approval from the Committee for Control and Supervision of Experiments on Animals (CPCSEA)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6, 2, 1, 4, 3, 5

Explanation:

Steps in drug development:

  1. Pre-clinical study CPCSEA approval: Ensuring the ethical treatment of animals in research.
  2. Initiate preclinical testing: Using GLP (Good Laboratory Practices) guidelines, animal studies are conducted to assess the safety and toxicity of drugs.
  3. IND application filing: Submit a new experimental drug application to CDSCO for a human clinical trial.
  4. Begin clinical trials: Conducted in four stages to evaluate the drug's efficacy and safety using the GCP guidelines (Good Clinical Practice).
  5. Approval from the Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO): To perform clinical studies and market the drug in India.
  6. NDA application filing: A new drug application is submitted to CDSCO for marketing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old Asian woman presents with acute eye pain and blurred vision. Her ophthalmologist suspects primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG). Which of the following statements about the etiopathogenesis of PACG is incorrect?

choices.text: Pupillary block is the most common mechanism in PACG
Phacomorphic mechanism involves an abnormally large lens pushing the iris forward
Plateau iris configuration is more common in younger patients with PACG
Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Caucasians have a higher prevalence of PACG compared to other ethnicities

 

Explanation:

  • PACG is more common in Asians compared to all other ethnicities.

Mechanisms of PACG

1. Pupillary block (70% of cases) (Option A ruled out):

  • Most common mechanism (70% of cases)
  • Increased contact between iris and lens

2. Plateau iris configuration:

  • Anteriorly positioned ciliary processes
  • More common in younger patients (Option C ruled out)

3. Phacomorphic mechanism (Option B ruled out):

  • Swollen lens contributes to angle closure
  • Can cause pupillary block or push peripheral iris forward

questions.text: Grade IV nerve injury in Sunderland classification corresponds to which type of nerve injury in Seddon’s classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Axonotmesis

 

Explanation:

Grade III Axonotmesis Damaged axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium

questions.text: Which of the following statements about HE4 and the Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm (ROMA) score is correct?

choices.text: HE4 is a marker that is specific for mucinous ovarian cancer.
The ROMA score combines HE4 and CA-125 levels with menopausal status to assess the risk of ovarian cancer.
HE4 is only useful in the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women.
The ROMA score is primarily used to predict the risk of breast cancer.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The ROMA score combines HE4 and CA-125 levels with menopausal status to assess the risk of ovarian cancer.

Explanation:

ROMA (Risk of Ovarian Malignancy Algorithm):

The combination of CA125 + HE4 (Human epididymal protein 4) tests, along with menopausal status, is used to help determine the likelihood of finding a malignancy on surgery in women with an adnexal mass. The combination of CA125 + HE4 accurately determines the likelihood of malignancy

 

Human epididymal protein 4 (HE4):

  • HE4: > 94% specificity; unaffected by endometriotic cysts
  • Differentiates benign from malignant ovarian tumors
  • Useful for early-stage ovarian cancer detection
  • Elevated in most serous and endometrioid tumors
  • Increased in 50% of clear cell tumors
  • Not elevated in mucinous tumors
  • Combined with CA-125, it detects ovarian and endometrial cancer


 

ROMA score: Risk of Malignancy Algorithm

Pre-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 12 + 2.38 x LN(HE4) + 0.0626 x LN (CA-125)

Post-menopausal Predictive Index (PI): 8.09 + 1.04 x LN(HE4) + 0.732 x LN (CA-125)

ROMA(%): 100 X Exp PI/ (1 + Exp PI)

ROMAcut-off: 7.4% for premenopausal women

25.3% postmenopausal women

 

HE4 is a marker that is specific for mucinous ovarian cancer (Option A): HE4 is a marker used for ovarian cancer but is not specific for mucinous ovarian cancer.

 

HE4 is only useful in the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in postmenopausal women (Option C): HE4 is useful in both premenopausal and postmenopausal women for ovarian cancer risk assessment.

 

The ROMA score is primarily used to predict the risk of breast cancer (Option D): The ROMA score is specifically designed for assessing the risk of ovarian cancer, not breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a protective factor against Peptic Ulcer Disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pepsin

 

Explanation:

Pepsin is not considered a protective factor for peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Excessive pepsin activity, especially in the presence of acid, can lead to tissue damage and ulcer formation. Therefore, pepsin is considered a contributing factor to ulceration rather than a protective factor against PUD.

Peptic Ulcer Disease

Protective factors

Damaging factors
  • Mucus (Option A)
  • Bicarbonate (Option B)
  • COX 1 (Option C)
  • HCl
  • Pepsin
  • H.pylori
  • Mucus and bicarbonate form a protective lining along the stomach wall, protecting it from the acids secreted by the stomach and parietal cells.
  • COX-1 is a gastroprotective enzyme, and its inhibition by NSAIDs such as aspirin can lead to peptic ulcer disease (PUD) as a side effect.

questions.text: Which of the following mortality indicators is a positive mortality indicator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Expectation of life

Explanation:

Mortality indicators:

Crude death rate

CDR = (Total no. or deaths in a community/ MYP (Mid-year population) in the same area) x 100

  • The mid-year population is taken on 1st July
  • Limitation: It does not consider the age and sex of the population

Age-specific death rate (Option A)

ASDR = (Total no. of deaths in a particular age group (eg. 20-24yrs) a given area in a year/ MYP of the age group in the same area and year) x 1000

Expectation of life

(Option C)
  • Life expectancy at birth: A positive mortality indicator· Average no. of years a newborn is expected to live, considering the current age-specific mortality rates in a community.
  • Important component to calculate the Human Development Index (HDI).
  • Life expectancy at one year is PQLI. In 2021, life expectancy in India is 69.7 years.

Infant mortality rate

IMR = (Total number of deaths (0-1-year-old) in a given year / Total number of live births in the same year) x 1000. It is a health status indicator.

Under-five mortality rate

U5MR = (Total number of deaths (0-5 years old) in a given year /Total number of live births in one year) x 1000

Maternal Mortality Rate

Maternal Mortality Rate (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/women in the reproductive age group [15-49 years]) x 100,000

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR)

Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) = (Total no. of maternal deaths/Live Births) x 100,000

Adult mortality rate

Probability of dying between 15 to 60 years of life

Year of potential life lost (Option D)

Premature death measurement. If life expectancy is 75 years, and death happens at age 30, then 45 years of potential life is lost

Proportional mortality rate (Option B)

The simplest measure of the burden of disease (Total deaths due to disease 'x'/ Total deaths in a community)́ x 100

Case fatality rate

CFR = (Deaths due to diseases ‘z’ / total no of cases of disease ‘z’) x 100

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and distension. An upright chest X-ray is performed, showing the following finding:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Pneumoperitoneum

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and radiological image indicate pneumoperitoneum, which can be identified by the classical Rigler sign (yellow arrows) seen in the given X-ray, also known as the double-wall sign, which is seen when gas outlines both sides of the bowel wall, i.e., gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity. Red arrows in the X-ray show gas under the diaphragm. 
  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, often indicating a perforated hollow viscus.

Pneumoperitoneum- Radiological findings

Imaging Modality

Key Findings of Pneumoperitoneum

Upright Chest X-ray
  • Subdiaphragmatic free gas
  • Continuous diaphragm sign

Supine Abdominal X-ray
  • Rigler's sign (gas within the bowel's lumen and gas within the peritoneal cavity)
  • Cupola sign (air beneath the dome of the diaphragm)
  • Football sign (oval-shaped collection of air in the upper abdomen)
  • Triangular air collection in Morrison's pouch

 

Rigler sign

Cupola sign

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the dose-response curves for benzodiazepines (Blue curve) and barbiturates (Red curve) is correct?

choices.text: Benzodiazepines demonstrate a steeper dose-response curve compared to barbiturates.
Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.
Both benzodiazepines and barbiturates display a linear dose-response relationship.
Benzodiazepines and barbiturates show similar potency but differ in their maximal efficacy on the dose-response curve.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index compared to barbiturates.

Explanation:

A linear dose-response relationship implies that the response increases proportionally with increasing dosage.

  • Benzodiazepines have a wider therapeutic index, making them safer for clinical use.

  • Barbiturates possess a narrow therapeutic index, meaning the difference between therapeutic and toxic doses is small, increasing the risk of overdose.

    • It exhibit a steeper dose-response curve, leading to a rapid progression from sedation to anesthesia and potentially fatal respiratory depression.

questions.text:
Match the following genes involved in the development of depression with their normal functions.

 


	
		
			
			Genes 
			
			
			Encoded for 
			
		
		
			
			A) SLC6A4
			
			
			i) Serotonin receptor
			
		
		
			
			B) DRD4
			
			
			ii) Dopamine transporter
			
		
		
			
			C) HTR1A
			
			
			iii) Serotonin transporter
			
		
		
			
			D) SLC6A3
			
			
			iv) Dopamine receptor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

 

Explanation:

 

Genetic Influence
  • About one-third of major depression risk is attributed to genetic factors.
  • The gene encoding of serotonin receptor: HTR1A
  • The gene for serotonin transporter: 5HTTP/SLC6A4
  • The gene for dopamine receptor: DRD4
  • The gene for dopamine transporter: SLC6A3

Family History
  • Risk increases 2.5–3 times if a first-degree relative has depression.
  • Life events can raise risk from 5 to 16 times shortly after occurrence.

Neurobiological Mechanisms

Studies show that individuals with the short allele of 5-HTTLPR (serotonin transporter gene) exhibit amygdala hyperreactivity to emotional threats

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of mechanical mitral valve replacement was on therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) during her pregnancy. Her last dose of LMWH was administered 12 hours ago and she is currently due for delivery after 7 days. What is the most appropriate management plan for anticoagulation in this patient ?

choices.text: Proceed with vaginal delivery without stopping LMWH and continue therapeutic dosing postpartum
Administer protamine sulfate to reverse the effects of LMWH before delivery
Transition from LMWH to unfractionated heparin 1 week prior to delivery
Proceed with cesarean delivery to avoid complications related to anticoagulation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Transition from LMWH to unfractionated heparin 1 week prior to delivery

 

Explanation: Low molecular weight heparin is to be replaced with unfractionated heparin 1 week prior to delivery as it has a faster action and easy reversibility.

 

Transition to unfractionated heparin (UFH) 1 week prior to labor or planned delivery is the preferred approach in patients requiring anticoagulation during pregnancy. UFH has a shorter half-life and is easier to reverse than LMWH, allowing flexibility in managing labor and delivery

  • Anticoagulation increases the risk of maternal hemorrhage during delivery.
  • Stopping anticoagulation too early increases the risk of thromboembolism, especially in high-risk patients like those with mechanical valves.
  • LMWH has a longer half-life and if labor begins before LMWH clears, there may be complications with bleeding or the inability to place regional anesthesia safely.
  • Unfractionated heparin (UFH) is preferred near delivery because:
    • It has a shorter half-life (~1.5 hours).
    • It can be stopped 4–6 hours before delivery or reversed with protamine sulfate if needed.
  • Anticoagulation is resumed postpartum after assessing bleeding risk.

Proceeding with vaginal delivery without stopping LMWH and continuing therapeutic dosing postpartum (Option A) increases the risk of uncontrolled hemorrhage thus it should not be done.

Administration of protamine sulfate to reverse the effects of LMWH before delivery (Option B) partially reverses LMWH but is not routinely used unless there is significant bleeding and moreover reversal of anticoagulation therapy increases the risk of thromboembolism in high risk patients

Proceeding with cesarean delivery to avoid complications related to anticoagulation (Option D) is not done as Cesarean delivery is not indicated solely due to anticoagulation unless there are obstetric or fetal indications. Vaginal delivery is the preferred mode of delivery for most women with heart disease, as it poses less hemodynamic stress.

Central Nervous System

Penile erection (used in depression with sexual dysfunction)

questions.text: A pregnant female at 14 weeks of gestation comes to the OPD for routine examination. On a pervaginal examination, there is a 2 cm dilation of the cervix. She also has a previous similar history of mid-trimester spontaneous abortion. You planned to do cervical cerclage. All are contraindications except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intact membrane

Explanation

An intact membrane is not a contraindication but rather a requirement for cerclage.

Contraindications of Cerclage:

  1. Intrauterine infection (Option A)
  2. Ruptured Membranes
  3. Presence of vaginal bleeding
  4. Severe uterine irritability
  5. Cervical dilation > 4cm.
  6. Fetal death,Anencephaly (Option B/D)

Types of cerclage: Shirodkar and McDonald

Removal of stitch: 37 weeks or earlier if labour pain starts

Time of Cerclage done:

  1. Prophylactic cerclage is done at 14 weeks of gestation
  2. Emergency cerclage can be done when the cervix is dilated, and the membranes are bulging.

questions.text: From the below given triple phase CT scan, which of the following statements is true regarding Liver cancer?

choices.text: Hypodense in arterial phase in HCC
Hyperdense in arterial phase in Metastasis liver disease
Hyperdense in non-contrast CT in HCC
Hypodense in venous phase in Metastasis liver disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hypodense in Venous phase in Metastasis liver disease

Explanation:

Triple-phase CT in Different Liver Pathologies

 

Phase

Arterial Phase

Portal Venous Phase

Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC)

Hypervascular with intense enhancement; lesion appears hyperdense compared to surrounding liver.

Washout of contrast; lesion appears hypodense (darker) compared to liver tissue.

Further washout; lesion remains hypodense or becomes isodense (similar density to liver).

Liver Metastasis
  • Hypovascular metastases appear hypodense.
  • Hypervascular metastases (e.g., neuroendocrine tumors) may show rim enhancement.

Lesions appear hypodense and become more distinct.

Lesions remain hypodense, continuing to stand out from liver tissue.

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a sedative drug whose dose-response curve, when plotted, is the same as below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option B) 2

Explanation:

 

In the graph given,

Median toxic dose (TD) = 200 mg

Median effective dose (ED) = 100

Effective dose in 100% population = 120

 

We know that Therapeutic index (TI)= TD50/ED50

200/100 = 2

Thus, the therapeutic index of the given sedative is 2

Clinically, the therapeutic range, which spans from the minimum effective dose to the maximum tolerated dose, is more useful.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male on warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation presents with uncontrolled bleeding. Laboratory tests show prolonged PT and INR. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the effect of warfarin on coagulation?

choices.text: Inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inhibition of Vitamin K epoxide reductase

Explanation: 

  • Warfarin inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, blocking regeneration of reduced vitamin K.

  • This prevents γ-carboxylation of vitamin K–dependent factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C & S, leading to prolonged PT/INR.

  • Early therapy may cause a transient prothrombotic state due to rapid fall in Protein C & S.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with irritation and redness at both eye corners, foamy discharge, and skin maceration as shown below. He also has chronic nasal discharge. Which organism is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Moraxella axenfeld

Explanation:

  • The presence of localized inflammation, redness, and foamy discharge confined to the angles of the eyes, along with skin maceration around these areas, points towards the diagnosis of angular conjunctivitis.
  • The most common cause is Moraxella axenfeld.
  • Infection is transmitted from the nasal cavity to the eyes via contaminated fingers or handkerchiefs.
  • Treatment: 
    • Oxytetracycline (1%) eye ointment applied 2-3 times a day for 9-14 days.
    • Zinc lotion is instilled during the day, and zinc oxide ointment at bedtime to inhibit the proteolytic enzyme and reduce maceration.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is scheduled for circumcision and is being assessed by an anaesthetist during the pre-anaesthesia checkup. What would be the most preferred type of anaesthesia for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caudal anaesthesia

Explanation:

  • Caudal epidural anaesthesia is a common practice in paediatric age groups.
  • It involves the insertion of a needle or catheter through the sacrococcygeal ligament, which covers the sacral hiatus formed by the un-fused laminae of S4 and S5.
  • It is frequently employed for procedures located below the diaphragm, such as urogenital, rectal, inguinal, and lower extremity surgeries.
  • In adults, it is employed for anorectal procedures, as it provides dense sacral sensory blockade with minimal upward spread.

Spinal anaesthesia (Option A) involves injecting anaesthetic into the cerebrospinal fluid but is generally not preferred for young children due to risks of hypotension and prolonged motor blockade.



 

General anaesthesia (Option B) induces unconsciousness and provides complete analgesia, but it carries risks such as airway complications and is often more than necessary for simple procedures like circumcision.

 

Local anaesthesia (Option C) consists of infiltrating anaesthetic agents at the surgical site to achieve localised analgesia. While effective for minor procedures, it may not provide adequate pain relief in paediatric patients who can be uncooperative during surgery.

questions.text:
Match the following deficiencies with their respective impacts:


 


	
		
			
			1) Adenosylcobalamin Deficiency
			
			
			a) Elevated homocysteine levels
			
		
		
			
			2) Methylcobalamin Deficiency
			
			
			b) Impaired energy production and chronic fatigue
			
		
		
			
			3) Methyl malonyl-CoA Mutase Deficiency
			
			
			c) Accumulation of methyl malonyl-CoA
			
		
		
			
			4) Methionine Synthase Deficiency
			
			
			d) Pernicious anaemia with immature red blood cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-c, 4-d 

Explanation:

  • Adenosylcobalamin → mitochondrial energy reactions → deficiency → fatigue.

  • Methylcobalamin → homocysteine → methionine → deficiency → ↑ homocysteine.

  • Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase → converts methylmalonyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA → defect → accumulation.

  • Methionine synthase → folate/B12 pathway → deficiency → megaloblastic anemia.

Takeaway:

  • B12 has two active forms—adenosylcobalamin (energy, methylmalonate clearance) and methylcobalamin (homocysteine metabolism, DNA synthesis).
  • Defects cause fatigue, ↑ homocysteine, ↑ methylmalonyl-CoA, and megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with schizophrenia presents with symptoms such as lack of interest, alogia, and diminished facial expressions. Which of the following findings is commonly associated with this type of schizophrenia according to Timothy Crow's classification?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Enlarged ventricles

Enlarged ventricles are a structural brain finding frequently seen in schizophrenia, mainly when negative symptoms are prominent, as in this case. This aligns with type II in Timothy Crow's classification.

 

Timothy Crow's classification

Type 1

Type 2

Associated with positive symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviour (Option A)

Presents with negative symptoms like Alogia, avolition, anhedonia

High dopamine levels (Option C)

Low dopamine levels

Normal ventricles (Option B)

Enlarged ventricles

Good response to medication

Poor response to medication

questions.text: Which of the following is the IV induction agent of choice in a patient with decompensated Cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propofol

Explanation:

Propofol is the IV induction agent of choice in patients with hepatic disease because it has a rapid onset and shorter recovery time, making it safer for these patients.

 

Anesthesia for patients with hepatic diseases:

  • IV induction agent of choice: Propofol
  • Muscle relaxants of choice: Cis-atracurium/Atracurium due to organ-independent Hoffman degradation (do not rely on renal or hepatic clearance)
  • Inhalational agent: Desflurane or Isoflurane, or Sevoflurane
  • Avoid using halothane: Risk of halothane-induced hepatitis
  • Narcotics used: Fentanyl, Sufentanil
  • Sedatives used: Oxazepam, Lorazepam
  • All long-acting narcotics and sedatives should be avoided in Cirrhotic patients.

Thiopentone (Option A): Prolonged recovery in liver disease.

Etomidate (Option C): Hemodynamically stable but not first choice.

Ketamine (Option D): Increases secretions and may worsen encephalopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the role of the phase difference between the oval and round windows in sound transmission?

choices.text: It amplifies sound waves by 10 dB
It prevents the cancellation of sound waves, allowing perilymph movement
It ensures simultaneous vibration of the oval and round windows
It decreases sound transmission efficiency, reducing hearing sensitivity by 4 dB

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It prevents the cancellation of sound waves, allowing perilymph movement

 

Explanation:

  • The phase difference between the oval window (which receives sound vibrations from the stapes) and the round window is crucial in preventing the cancellation of sound waves.
  • The oval window receives compression waves, while the round window experiences the rarefaction phase, allowing proper movement of the perilymph in the cochlea.
  • Without this phase difference, sound waves reaching the two windows at the same time would cancel each other out, leading to no movement of the perilymph and ineffective sound transmission.

 

It amplifies sound waves by 10 dB (Option A): The phase difference between the oval and round windows contributes to sound transmission but does not amplify sound by 10 dB. The actual contribution of the phase difference to hearing sensitivity is about 4 dB, not 10 dB.

 

It ensures simultaneous vibration of the oval and round windows (Option C): The oval and round windows do not vibrate simultaneously. In fact, their non-simultaneous movement is what prevents the cancellation of sound waves and ensures proper movement of the perilymph.

 

It decreases sound transmission efficiency, reducing hearing sensitivity by 4 dB (Option D): The phase difference between the oval and round windows actually enhances sound transmission efficiency and contributes to increasing hearing sensitivity by about 4 dB, not decreasing it.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease recently received a compatible donor organ from her brother. The kidney transplant surgery proceeds as planned, but within minutes of reperfusion, the kidney becomes mottled, cyanotic and anuric. What is the cause for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Preformed antibodies in the recipient

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests hyperacute graft rejection due to preformed antibodies in the recipient.

Hyperacute Graft Rejection

  • Hyperacute Graft Rejection is the most rapid and catastrophic form of graft rejection, occurring immediately on the operating table or within the first 48 hours of transplantation.
  • Pathogenesis: Hyperacute rejection is caused by preformed circulating IgG antibodies against donor antigens (mainly HLA or ABO), which may arise from prior pregnancies, multiple blood transfusions, or previous organ transplants.
  • Mechanism: Preformed antibodies bind to donor endothelial antigens, activating complement and causing widespread thrombosis, vascular occlusion, ischemia, and graft necrosis, leading to a kidney that rapidly becomes cyanotic, flaccid, and anuric (sometimes with a few drops of blood).
  • Clinical features: Hyperacute rejection presents with a mottled blue ischemic kidney, loss of graft tone, and absent urine output (anuria) or occasionally hematuria (few drops of blood).
  • Immunologically, hyperacute rejection represents a Type II hypersensitivity reaction mediated by antibodies.

questions.text: A 38 y/o male presents with chronic pain and intermittent purulent discharge from a sinus over his right tibia, which developed after a fracture sustained 8 months ago. An X-ray shows the following finding. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the persistence of his infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lack of initial antibiotic therapy

 

Explanation:

The X-ray clearly shows a sequestrum in the distal femur. This indicates that the infection has progressed to a chronic stage, and lack of initial antibiotic therapy likely the primary reason for the persistent infection.

 

Sequestrum Formation and Surfaces:

Definition: A sequestrum is a piece of dead bone separated from healthy bone, often seen in chronic osteomyelitis.

 

Causes:

  1. Infection and Inflammation: Bacterial infection in the bone (usually in the metaphysis) triggers inflammation, increasing internal bone pressure.
  2. Vascular Compromise: The pus causes thrombosis of the blood vessels within the bone, both in the medullary cavity and the periosteum.
  3. Necrosis and Sequestrum Formation: This blockage of blood flow deprives a segment of the bone of oxygen and nutrients, leading to necrosis (tissue death). This dead bone becomes a sequestrum.
  4. Persistence of Infection: Sequestrum remains avascular, allowing bacteria to thrive and evade immune response and antibiotics.
  • Note: The outer surface of the sequestrum is rough as it is in contact with the granulation tissue trying to “eat it” away. Whereas the inner surface is smooth.

Clinical Significance of Sequestra:

  • Persistence of Infection: This leads to chronic osteomyelitis due to bacteria hiding in the sequestrum.
  • Impaired Healing: Sequestra hinder bone healing and resolution of infection.
  • Surgical Implications: Sequestrectomy (removal of sequestrum) and debridement are often required to treat chronic osteomyelitis.

Sequestrum formation (Option B)-  forms due to persistence of Infection

Incomplete fracture healing (Option C): This could lead to delayed recovery but is less likely to directly cause the persistence of infection with chronic discharge.

Soft tissue abscess (Option D): Abscesses can cause localised infection but do not explain the persistent bone involvement as seen with sequestra.

questions.text: A critically injured victim makes a statement about the circumstances of their injury before passing away. Which of the following correctly distinguishes between a dying declaration and a dying deposition in this scenario?

choices.text: A dying declaration must be recorded by a Magistrate, while a dying deposition can be recorded by anyone
A dying deposition requires the presence of the accused's counsel, while a dying declaration does not
A dying declaration has less legal value compared to a dying deposition
A dying declaration is always recorded under oath, while a dying deposition is not

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A dying deposition requires the presence of the accused's counsel, while a dying declaration does not

Explanation:
In a dying deposition, the accused or his counsel is always present, while in a dying declaration, they are not present.

Dying Declaration vs Dying Deposition

Feature

Dying Declaration

Dying Deposition

Recorder

Anyone—Magistrate/doctor/village headman/police/any member of the public

Always recorded by a Magistrate

Oath

Not required

Must be taken

Accused or his counsel

Not present

Always present

Cross-examination

Not done

Done

Legal value

Comparatively less

Much more

Admissibility if declarant survives

Not admitted, but has corroborative value

Fully admitted

Nature

Merely recording of statement

Complete court procedure

Type of evidence

Documentary

Oral

Status in India

Followed

Not followed

Dying declaration can be recorded by anyone, including a Magistrate, doctor, village headman, police, or any member of the public. A dying deposition is always recorded by a Magistrate.(Option A)

Dying deposition has more legal value compared to a dying declaration. (Option C)

Dying deposition is recorded under oath, this is not required in case of dying declaration.(Option D)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and nausea. An ultrasound shows significant thickening of the gallbladder wall and hyperproliferation of the mucosa. Which of the following is NOT a USG finding in Adenomyomatosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Porcelain appearance

 

Explanation:

Porcelain appearance is usually seen as associated with calcifications of the gall bladder and not adenomyomatosis

Adenomyomatosis

Definition: A benign condition characterised by hyperplastic changes in the gallbladder wall, often associated with cholesterol stones.

Characteristics:

  • Hyperplastic Changes:
    • Overgrowth of the gallbladder mucosa.
    • Significant thickening of the muscle layer.
    • Deposition of cholesterol crystals in the deep Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound Findings:
    • Diamond ring sign. (Option A)
    • Comet tail artefacts. (Option B)
    • V-shaped artefacts. (Option C)

 

 

Treatment:

Symptomatic Patients with Gallstones: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department following minor trauma from bumping into a table corner. Physical examination reveals a bluish discoloration on the thigh. Based on its appearance, what is the most likely age of the bruise?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Few hours to 3 days

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with difficulty in adducting his thigh after sustaining an injury during a soccer match. Upon examination, weakness in adduction and medial rotation of the thigh is noted. Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for these actions, and what is its nerve supply?

choices.text: Adductor part of adductor magnus; Obturator nerve (posterior division)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Adductor part of adductor magnus; Obturator nerve (posterior division)

 

Explanation:

  • The adductor part of the adductor magnus muscle is primarily responsible for thigh adduction and medial rotation.
  • It is innervated by the obturator nerve, specifically the posterior division.
  • The weakness observed in these actions following the injury indicates the involvement of adductor magnus.
