questions.text:
A 6-year-old child presents with progressive bone marrow failure, short stature, and multiple congenital abnormalities. The child also has distinct skin lesions as shown below. Radiological imaging reveals the following features.

  





Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation

 

Explanation:

  • The above radiological image of absent thumb and radius, along with the history of short stature, progressive bone marrow failure, and café-au-lait macules (hypopigmented skin lesions), is suggestive of Fanconi anemia.
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) is the only curative therapy for Fanconi anemia.

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

Features

Absent thumbs, absent radius, microcephaly, renal abnormalities, short stature, café-au-lait spots

Treatment

  • Supportive care - PRBC and platelets transfusion, antibiotics for infection, oral androgens
  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplant (curative) 
  • Horse anti-thymocyte globulin, cyclosporine (contraindicated in children)

Risk of malignancy

AML, myelodysplasia, oral or liver cancer

questions.text: Which of the following would decrease the conduction velocity of an action potential along an axon?

choices.text: Increasing the diameter of the axon.
Decreasing the capacitance of the membrane.
Increasing the myelination of the axon.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increasing the axoplasmic resistance.

Explanation:

  • Increasing this resistance would hinder the spread of Na+ ions, making it more difficult to reach the threshold for action potential initiation at adjacent nodes of Ranvier.
  • Conduction velocity depends on axon diameter, myelination, internal resistance, and membrane capacitance.

    • ↑ Axoplasmic resistance → slows Na⁺ spread → ↓ conduction velocity 

    • ↑ Diameter & myelination → increase velocity

    • ↓ Capacitance → faster depolarization

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student reports a persistent, irrational fear of blood. She states that seeing blood, even in movies, makes her feel faint and nauseous. This has caused her to avoid medical procedures and prevented her from volunteering for first aid training, which is required for her degree. Her symptoms have been present since childhood. Which of the following would be the most effective initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Behavioral therapy with exposure therapy

Explanation:

Behavioral therapy with exposure therapy is the most effective treatment for specific phobias, including blood phobia (hemophobia). In exposure therapy, the individual is gradually exposed to the feared object or situation in a safe, controlled manner, helping to reduce the intensity of the fear response over time.

 

Specific phobias

  • Strong, persistent, irrational fear of a specific object/situation.
  • Specific phobia is the persistence of this fear for 6 months or more.

 

Symptoms:

  • Exposure to the object/situation causes immediate fear, panic, and/or anxiety.
  • Avoidance behaviors: of the object or situation.
  • The fear/anxiety is out of proportion to the likely threat.
  • Marked distress or impairment psychosocially.
  • DSM-5
    • Animal (e.g., Dogs, Cats, Spiders)
    • Natural environment (e.g., Water, heights)
    • Blood-Injection-Needle (e.g., Needles, Invasive Medical Procedures)
    • Situational (e.g., Closed places, Planes)
    • Others

 

Common phobias

Acrophobia

Fear of height

Ailurophobia

Cats

Cynophobia

Dogs

Claustrophobia

Closed spaces

Mysophobia

Dirt and Germs

Hydrophobia

Water

Thanatophobia

Death

Nyctophobia

Dark

Xenophobia

Strangers

Pyrophobia

Fire

Hemophobia

Blood

Arachnophobia

Spiders


 

Treatment:

Psychosocial therapy:

  • The strategy of choice is behavioral therapy (Option A)
    • Exposure therapy - systematic desensitization
    • Reinforcing the realization that the phobic stimulus is safe and not dangerous.
    • Techniques to deal with anxiety - relaxation and breathing control.
    • The patients keep moving up the scale until the most anxiety-provoking stimuli no longer elicit any fear or anxiety (Desensitized).
    • Flooding (Implosion): Increasing exposure to the stimulus to induce habituation and decrease anxiety- no longer preferred.
  • Virtual therapy
  • Hypnosis
  • Supportive therapy
  • Family therapy

Pharmacological therapy:

  • Treat comorbid conditions.
  • For example, beta-blockers and benzodiazepines for panic attacks.

 

Serotonin-Norepinephrine reuptake Inhibitor (SNRI) (Option B): They are used in treating generalized anxiety disorders, depression, and panic disorders, but they are not first-line treatments for specific phobias. Medications are generally not as effective for treating specific phobias as psychotherapy, particularly exposure-based techniques. This option is incorrect.

 

Short-term benzodiazepines (Option C): They can be used for temporary relief of acute anxiety in phobia-related situations, but they are not considered a long-term treatment or the most effective approach for specific phobias. This option is incorrect.

 

Antipsychotic medication (Option D): They are used as second-line drugs to treat anxiety-related disorders. They are not indicated for the treatment of specific phobias such as hemophobia. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden confusion, fever, and seizures over the past 24 hours. Her partner reports memory loss and difficulty recognising faces. Examination reveals a fever of 102°F, disorientation, and mild aphasia. PCR is positive for HSV. Which feature is not associated with the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mollaret meningitis

Explanation:

  • The scenario presenting with seizures, aphasia, disorientation, confusion, fever, and positive PCR testing for HSV indicates a diagnosis of herpes simplex virus encephalitis caused by HSV-1.
  • Mollaret meningitis is recurrent aseptic meningitis associated with HSV-2, not HSV-1.

Clinical manifestations of Herpes simplex virus

  • Cutaneous:
    • Site:
      • Face (cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead)
      • Buttocks (infants as napkin rash)
    • 'Fever blister' or herpes febrile or cold sores (viral reactivation in febrile patients)
    • Herpetic whitlow: Occupational variety seen in doctors, dentists, and nurses.
    • Eczema herpeticum: Generalised crops of vesicles appear in the affected area with widespread ulceration, as seen in children with eczema.
    • Herpes gladiatorum (Wrestler’s herpes): In athletes who play skin-to-skin contact sports like wrestlers.
    • Herpes multiforme (red, raised, target-like lesions on skin)

 

  • Mucosal
    • Site: Buccal mucosa (most common)
    • Gingivostomatitis and pharyngitis (primary infection) (Option A)
    • Recurrent herpes labialis (Option B)
  • Ophthalmic
    • Dendritic corneal ulcers (Option D)
    • Corneal blindness and conjunctivitis are also observed
    • Chorioretinitis and acute necrotising retinitis are rare.
  • Nervous system
    • Encephalitis (HSV Encephalitis)
      • Caused by HSV-1
      • Most common cause of sporadic acute viral encephalitis
      • Affected site: Temporal lobe
    • Meningitis
      • Most commonly caused by HSV-2
      • Mollaret meningitis (recurrent lymphocytic meningitis) (Option C)
      • HSV can result in Bell's palsy.
  • Visceral
    • Symptoms like dysphagia, substernal pain and weight loss.
    • Tracheobronchitis and pneumonitis (lung involvement)
  • Genital infections
    • Mostly seen in HSV type 2
    • Bilateral, painful genital vesiculo-ulcerative lesions
    • Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy
    • Site: Lesions are mainly seen on,
      • Male: The penis or in the urethra (urethritis).
      • Female: The cervix, vagina, vulva and perineum.
  • Congenital
    • If a pregnant woman has genital lesions during labour, the risk of infection can be mitigated by performing a cesarean section.
    • Neonatal herpes: A disseminated disease involving multiple organs, with or without encephalitis. The mortality rate is high, and survivors may have neurological impairments.
    • Transplacental infections leading to congenital malformations are rare.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for ICD implantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • While Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome can lead to arrhythmias, it is typically amenable to catheter ablation, making ICD implantation unnecessary in the absence of other risk factors.

Indication for ICD implantation

  • Ischemic, Non-ischemic, Hypertrophic (Option C ruled out), and Familial cardiomyopathy 
  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia
  • Cardiac sarcoidosis
  • Brugada syndrome
  • Long-QT syndrome (Option D ruled out)
  • Catecholaminergic polymorphic VT (CPVT)
  • LV noncompaction
  • Chagas disease (dilated cardiomyopathy due to infection) (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: A public health officer is investigating an outbreak of a viral illness in a tropical region. The affected individuals present with symptoms such as fever, maculopapular skin rash, conjunctivitis, and joint pain. The officer needs to identify the primary vector responsible for the transmission of the virus to implement effective control measures. Which vector is primarily responsible for transmitting the virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aedes aegypti mosquito

Explanation:

Zika virus disease should be considered in patients with acute onset of fever, maculopapular rash, and arthralgia, particularly if they have travelled to areas with ongoing transmission in the two weeks before symptom onset. Zika virus is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.

Zika virus disease:

  • Agent: Zika virus is a Flavivirus transmitted via mosquito bite; hence, it is called an arbovirus.
  • Mode of Transmission:
    • Transmitted by the bite of an infected Aedes aegypti mosquito, which tends to bite during the morning and late afternoon.
    • It is also increasingly recognized that an infected pregnant woman can pass the virus to her baby during pregnancy or near the time of birth.
  • Clinical Symptoms: Fever, skin rash, conjunctivitis, joint pain, headache. Symptoms are usually mild and last 2-7 days. Pregnant women are at increased risk for developing both fetal and maternal complications.
  • Prevention: Prevention and control depend on reducing mosquitoes by removing and modifying breeding sites.

Anopheles mosquito (Option A): Primarily known for transmitting malaria.

Culex mosquito (Option B): Primarily known for transmitting West Nile virus and other arboviruses.

Ixodes tick (Option D): Known for transmitting Lyme disease and other tick-borne illnesses unrelated to mosquito-borne diseases.

questions.text: A 50 y/o man undergoes a total hip replacement. Postoperatively, he develops difficulty walking and reports numbness along the posterior thigh, lateral leg, and sole of the foot. O/E, he has weakness in extending the hip and flexing the knee. The injured nerve originates from which of the following spinal roots?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4–S3

 

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms, including weakness in hip extension, knee flexion, and sensory loss along the posterior thigh and leg, are indicative of sciatic nerve injury.

  • The sciatic nerve originates from the ventral rami of the L4–S3 spinal roots.

    • L2–L4 (Option A) forms the femoral/obturator nerves.

    • L5–S1 (Option C) is part of the sacral plexus but not the full sciatic root

    • S1–S5 (Option D) contributes to the pudendal and coccygeal nerves.

Takeaway:

Sciatic nerve = largest nerve, root value L4–S3, vulnerable in hip surgery/injections.

 

 

Sciatic Nerve course

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a 4-year-old child is assessed using Waterlow's Classification. The child's height-for-age is found to be 85%, while weight-for-height is 85%. According to Waterlow's Classification, the nutritional status of this child would be categorized as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stunted

 

Explanation:

According to Waterlow’s criteria, Weight for height ≥ 80% and Height for Age < 90% is termed as Stunted.

 

Weight for Height

Height for Age

Nutritional Status

≥ 80%

≥ 90%

Normal

< 80%

≥ 90%

Wasted

≥ 80%

< 90%

Stunted

< 80%

< 90%

Wasted and Stunted

Other classifications of malnutrition include the Gomez classification and the Wellcome Trust classification.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fever, offensive vaginal discharge, and lower abdominal pain following a spontaneous abortion at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, she has uterine tenderness. Ultrasound shows no evidence of spread beyond the uterus. What is the most likely clinical grade of her septic abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Grade I

Explanation:

Grade I septic abortion involves localized infection confined to the uterus. In this case, the absence of spread beyond the uterus on ultrasound and the patient's symptoms suggest a localized infection.

 

  • Septic abortion includes both spontaneous and induced abortions in pregnancies under 20 weeks gestation complicated by severe uterine infections like endometritis and parametritis.
  • Clinical Criteria: Includes fever ≥100.4°F (38°C), foul vaginal discharge, lower abdominal pain and tenderness.
  • Presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Chills, tachycardia, and malaise are also common.

 

Grade

Description

Management

I

(Option A)

Localized infection in the uterus

Hospitalization, Antibiotics, Uterine evacuation post-antibiotics if indicated

II

(Option B)

The infection spreads beyond the uterus (parametrium, tubes, ovaries)

Broad-spectrum antibiotics, Analgesics, Anti-tetanus serum, Clinical monitoring, Delayed evacuation

III

(Option C)

Generalized peritonitis or shock, often from illegal abortions

Intensive antibiotics, Supportive therapy, Emergency surgery if needed

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought by her family. They report that over the past year, she has been using increasing amounts of opioids, initially prescribed for chronic back pain. The patient admits to using opioids in larger amounts than intended and has made several unsuccessful attempts to cut down. She has given up her hobbies and often misses work due to opioid use. Recently, she was arrested for stealing prescription pads from her doctor's office. Despite these issues, she continues to use opioids daily. Which of the following statements BEST characterizes this patient's condition based on the information provided?

choices.text: The patient meets criteria for opioid dependence, with evidence of tolerance and withdrawal
The patient exhibits opioid abuse but does not meet the full criteria for dependence due to the absence of physiological symptoms
The patient meets the criteria for opioid dependence, with prominent features of impaired control and social impairment
The patient's behavior suggests opioid misuse rather than dependence, as the initial use was medically sanctioned

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The patient meets the criteria for opioid dependence, with prominent features of impaired control and social impairment

Explanation:

The behavioral and clinical features of the patient align with the diagnostic criteria for substance dependence according to DSM-5, as given below:

  1. Impaired control: The patient uses opioids in larger amounts than intended and has made unsuccessful attempts to cut down.
  2. Social impairment: She has given up hobbies and often misses work due to opioid use.
  3. Continued use despite consequences: She continues to use despite legal problems (arrested for stealing prescription pads) and negative impacts on her life.

 

Dependence:

Dependence is a state where a person exhibits both physical and psychological symptoms related to substance use.

 

Type of Dependence

Definition

Behavioral Dependence

Focuses on substance-seeking behaviors and the patterns of pathological use.

Physical Dependence

Refers to the physiological effects that result from repeated episodes of substance use.

Psychological Dependence

Also called habituation, characterized by a persistent or occasional craving to avoid dysphoria.

 

Substance Use Disorder Criteria (DSM-5):

The criteria for diagnosing substance dependence can be grouped into four main categories:

  1. Impaired Control:
    • Using larger amounts or for longer periods than intended
    • Persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control use
    • Spending excessive time obtaining, using, or recovering from the substance
    • Experiencing intense cravings or urges to use the substance
  2. Social Impairment:
    • Failing to fulfill major role obligations due to substance use
    • Continuing use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems
    • Giving up important activities because of substance use (Progressive Neglect)
  3. Risky Use:
    • Recurrent use in physically hazardous situations
    • Continued use despite knowledge of physical or psychological problems caused or exacerbated by the substance (Persistence)
  4. Pharmacological Criteria:
    • Tolerance: Needing increased amounts to achieve desired effects or experiencing reduced effects with the same amount
    • Withdrawal: Experiencing characteristic withdrawal symptoms or using the substance to relieve withdrawal.

 

(Option A): While the patient likely meets the criteria for opioid dependence, the scenario doesn't provide explicit evidence of tolerance or withdrawal.

(Option B) is incorrect because the patient's presentation goes beyond abuse and meets the criteria for dependence.

(Option D) is incorrect because the origin of use (medically sanctioned) doesn't prevent a diagnosis of dependence. The pattern of use, loss of control, and continued use despite significant problems all point to dependence rather than mere misuse.

questions.text: A 43-year-old Man presents with increased mouth secretions, mild respiratory difficulty, and a heart rate of 52 bpm after eating sushi. While being examined, the patient loses consciousness. The patient is given atropine. Which of the following describes the action of atropine on heart rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Initial bradycardia followed by tachycardia

Explanation: 

Effects of atropine on heart rate:

  • Atropine, when administered parenterally, causes initial bradycardia followed by tachycardia. (Option A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Atropine initially blocks the M1 receptors, causing an increase in ACh, which in turn causes initial bradycardia.
  • As the atropine concentration increases, it blocks M2 receptors on the SA node, which leads to a decrease in ACh, causing tachycardia.

questions.text: An egg was extracted and observed under the microscope. Which of the following species does it belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hymenolepis nana

 

Explanation:

This is an egg of Hyenopelsis nana.

 

 

  • Size: 30–50 μm in diameter.
  • Shape: Oval or spherical with a thin shell.
  • Inner membrane/embryophore: Characterized by polar filaments extending into the space between the inner and outer shell.
  • Embryo: Contains an oncosphere with three pairs of hooklets.

questions.text: Which organism does this life cycle belong to?
questions.solution:
This is the life cycle of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease.

The life cycle involves several stages and hosts:

  1. Triatomine Bug (Vector Stage): The cycle begins when a triatomine bug ("kissing bug") feeds on the blood of a human. During this feeding, the bug defecates, and the faeces containing the infective stage (metacyclic trypomastigotes) are introduced into the wound or mucous membranes.
  2. Trypomastigote Stage: Once inside the host, the metacyclic trypomastigotes invade host cells and transform into intracellular amastigotes. In this stage, they multiply by binary fission.
  3. Amastigote Stage: Inside the host cells (particularly in muscle and nerve tissues), the amastigotes reproduce and eventually transform back into trypomastigotes, which then burst out of the cells and enter the bloodstream.
  4. Re-infection in the Vector: When another triatomine bug bites an infected host, it ingests the trypomastigotes present in the blood. Inside the bug, the trypomastigotes transform back into epimastigotes and multiply in the insect’s gut. Eventually, they differentiate into metacyclic trypomastigotes, ready to infect another host.
  • In the Reduvid bug: Epimastigote and trypomastigote are seen.
  • In adults: Amastigote and trypomastigote are seen.


 

T. cruzi trypomastigotes in peripheral blood smear

questions.text: A new drug designed to lower cholesterol levels is being tested. The testing involved 1000 participants. The null hypothesis is that "the new drug does not affect cholesterol levels". After analysing the data, the researchers conclude that the drug doesn't work, but in reality, it does have a small but clinically significant effect. What type of error has occurred?

choices.text: Both Type I and Type II errors

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type II error

Explanation:

This scenario describes a Type II error, also known as a "false negative."

  • Type II error occurs when we fail to reject a false null hypothesis.
  • In this case, a potentially beneficial drug might be overlooked.
  • Type II errors are particularly important in medical research, as they can lead to overlooking potentially beneficial treatments.
  • The power of a statistical test (1 - probability of Type II error) is crucial in designing studies to minimise this risk.

Type I error (Option A) occurs when you reject a true null hypothesis.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases can be treated with a drug that inhibits vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT)?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Huntington’s chorea

EXPLANATION:

Movement disorders like Huntington’s chorea and tardive dyskinesia can be treated with drugs that inhibit vesicular monoamine transporters (VMAT).

  • As the name suggests, VMATs are transporters of monoamines, especially catecholamines (adrenaline, noradrenaline, and dopamine), within storage vesicles.
  • They are mainly of three types - VMAT 1, VMAT 2 & VAchT.

Centrally, this process mainly involves the release of dopamine, which is abnormal in movement disorders involving excessive dopaminergic activity.

Peripherally, this process occurs at the synaptic terminals, which are responsible for maintaining blood pressure; hence, these drugs were once used to manage hypertension.

Inhibitors: Tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, valbenazine

Inhibitor: Reserpine

These drugs selectively inhibit VMAT-1

This drug inhibits both VMAT-1 & VMAT-2

questions.text:
Match the following corneal assessment techniques with their correct descriptions:


	
		
			
			1) Keratometry
			
			
			a) Measures both anterior and posterior corneal surfaces.
			
		
		
			
			2) Placido's Disc
			
			
			b) Assesses the smoothness and curvature of the corneal surface.
			
		
		
			
			3) Corneal Topography
			
			
			c) Evaluate the anterior curvature of the cornea and generate colour-coded maps.
			
		
		
			
			4) Corneal Tomography (Pentacam)
			
			
			d) Measures the curvature of the central cornea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

Explanation:

Instrument

Image

Keratometry

  • Definition: Objective measurement of central corneal curvature to assess astigmatism

  • Principle: Image size analysis of anterior cornea using visible doubling

  • Normal Values: Average ~45 D; >45 D in keratoconus

  • Types: Javal-Schiotz, Bausch & Lomb
 

Auto refractive Keratometer

Keratoscopy / Placido’s Disc

  • Disc with alternating black & white rings

  • Assesses corneal surface smoothness & curvature

  • Normal: Uniform, sharp ring reflections

  • Abnormal: Distorted rings → corneal irregularities

Corneal Topography

  • Evaluates anterior corneal curvature

  • Produces colour-coded maps (shape, curvature, elevation)

  • Uses: Diagnose keratoconus, plan refractive surgery

  • Limitation: No information on posterior corneal surface

Corneal Tomography (Pentacam)

  • Measures anterior & posterior corneal surfaces

  • Gives 3D corneal structure

  • Detects subclinical keratoconus

  • Assesses refractive surgery candidates

  • Uses Scheimpflug imaging for accurate measurements

  • Helpful in pre-op evaluation & disease monitoring

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has undergone cataract surgery. He has now returned after 6 weeks with endophthalmitis. What is the most likely organism that caused the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Propionibacterium acnes

 

Explanation:

The scenario is that of late-onset postoperative endophthalmitis

  • Endophthalmitis is inflammation of the inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers

 

Delayed onset endophthalmitis:

 

Onset

  • After 6-weeks of intraocular surgery

Course
  • Slow, with a panuveitis-like picture

Clinical Features
  • Granulomatous keratic precipitates
  • Inflammatory deposits over intraocular lens (IOL)
  • White capsular plaque
  • Anterior chamber reaction
  • Vitritis
  • Cystoid macular edema (CME)

Response to Treatment
  • May respond to periocular or systemic steroids but usually recurs

Common Causative Organisms
  • Bacterial: Propionibacterium acnes (most common), Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus
  • Fungal: Aspergillus, Candida, and others

questions.text: A researcher is interested in examining the prevalence of hypertension among adults in a city and wants to identify any associated risk factors such as age, diet, and physical activity at a single time. The researcher collects data from a large sample of adults in the city. Which type of study design is the researcher using in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cross-sectional study

 

Explanation:

  • A cross-sectional study is used to determine the prevalence of a disease in a population at a specific time.
  • It is also known as a snapshot of the total population.
  • Here it is cross-sectional study because it calculates prevalence of a disease and relies on primary data, i.e., researcher collects the data himself.
  • To assess the incidence, a Cohort study (Option A) starts by determining whether risk factors are present.
  • Case-control study (Option C) determines whether an exposure is associated with an outcome. It starts with diseased and non-diseased.
  • An Ecological study (Option D) compares exposure and disease frequency in a series of populations. The unit of study is population. Ecological study uses secondary data.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a firm, immobile mass in her right breast for the past few days. 2 weeks ago, she bruised her breast while exercising. A mammogram reveals scattered punctate calcifications within the lump. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fat Necrosis

Explanation: The most likely diagnosis in this patient with recent trauma and calcification could be fat necrosis.

  • Breast fat necrosis is caused by injured or ischemic breast tissue that is replaced with scar tissue and presents as a palpable nodule.
  • It is commonly caused by breast trauma and breast surgical procedures.
  • It presents as a mammographic density, a painless palpable lump, skin thickening, or deposits of calcium.
  • Fat necrosis can manifest in a variety of ways that closely resemble cancer like irregular breast mass, usually fixed to the dermis, with possible skin tethering and/or nipple retraction as a result of fibrotic bands between necrotic tissue and skin.
  • Calcifications can sometimes occur in fat necrosis, particularly in older lesions. These are typically punctate (tiny dots) and scattered throughout the lump, unlike some cancers (differentiated by biopsy).

Mastitis(Option A): This is an infection of breast tissue, often caused by bacteria entering through milk ducts during breastfeeding. It can cause inflammation, redness, pain, fever, and chills, which are absent in this case.

Breast Abscess(Option B) This is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, often caused by a bacterial infection. It presents with fever, chills, and a more fluctuant (fluid-filled) mass compared to the firm mass often felt with fat necrosis.

Inflammatory Breast Cancer(Option D): It typically presents with additional symptoms like skin thickening, peau d'orange (skin resembling an orange peel), and rapid progression.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant presented with sudden choking on a small toy part while playing. The infant appears cyanotic and is making weak, ineffective attempts to breathe. What is the most appropriate initial intervention for this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Deliver five back blows.

 

Explanation:

  • Back blows are the first step to relieve airway obstruction in infants under 1 year.

 

Upper Airway Foreign Body Aspiration:

Causes

Choking on small objects such as toy parts, seeds, nuts, grapes, pebbles, or buttons.

Presentation

Sudden onset of cough, gagging or stridor with or without respiratory distress.

Type of Obstruction
  • Severe Obstruction: Universal choking sign (clutching the neck), weak or no cough, inability to speak or breathe, cyanosis.
  • Mild Obstruction: Breathing is possible, with possible wheezing, coughing, and stridor.

Immediate Removal Indication

Severe obstruction requires urgent intervention.

Procedure for Infants (<1 year)
  • Back Blows: Place the infant face down over the rescuer’s arm, head lower than the trunk, and deliver five back blows between the scapulae. (Option C)
  • Chest Compressions: If obstruction persists, turn the infant over and perform five chest compressions. (Option B)
  • Sequence: Repeat back blows and chest compressions until the obstruction is relieved or the infant becomes unconscious.

Procedure for Children (>1 year)

(Option A)

Heimlich Maneuver: Perform abdominal thrusts.

​​​​​​​

 

Complications

  • Chest Compressions: May cause rib or cardiac damage, though rare.
  • Heimlich Maneuver: If performed incorrectly, the manoeuvre can cause pneumomediastinum, rupture of the spleen or stomach, and injury to the aorta.


 

Give rescue breaths (Option D): Rescue breaths are part of CPR, which is not the first step in this scenario.

questions.text:
Match the parts of the Papez circuit with their correct functions:


	
		
			
			Part of Papez Circuit
			
			
			Function

			C) Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain
			
		
		
			
			4) Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus
			
			
			D) Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1 - B, 2 - D, 3 - A, 4 - C

Explanation:
The Papez circuit is a neurocircuitry of the limbic system involved in learning and memory, emotion, and social behavior.

 

It has the following components:

Part of Papez Circuit

Function

Cingulate Gyrus

Controls heart rate, blood pressure, cognitive and emotional processing.

Parahippocampal Gyrus and Entorhinal Cortex

Spatial memory, the memory of three-dimensional space.

Hippocampus

Responsible for the conversion of short-term memory to long-term memory.

Mammillary Body and Anterior Nucleus of Thalamus

Responsible for controlling recent memories of the brain.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient presents with poorly controlled hypertension despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. The physician initiates Clonidine therapy to help manage the patient's blood pressure. Which of the following is TRUE regarding the mechanism of action of Clonidine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Stimulates α2-adrenergic receptors.

Explanation:

 

Clonidine reduces sympathetic outflow from the CNS by agonising α2-adrenergic receptors.

 

Mechanism of action

questions.text: Elderly man had undergone PCI with stenting 6 weeks ago. Today he passed fresh blood in stool and then collapses in the washroom. On admission pulse is 130 /min, low volume and BP is 80/60 mm Hg. His wife tells that yesterday he was complaining of melena. Medication history is of use of aspirin and clopidogrel for last 6 weeks. Which of the following investigations should be done to determine source of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Upper GI Endoscopy

  • Patient is having upper GI bleeding due to use of aspirin. Erosive gastritis / PUD would have caused melena initially and later haematochezia.
  • Colonoscopy is typically reserved for when upper GI endoscopy is negative or when bleeding is clearly from the lower GI tract.
  • Stool occult blood testing is not useful here because the bleeding is overt, and the patient is unstable.
  • Abdominal ultrasound will not help in identifying the source of GI bleeding.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic osteoarthritis presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. He has been taking an NSAID for pain management for the past few months. On examination, he appears diaphoretic and in distress. The ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Troponin levels are elevated. What is the most likely drug causing this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Rofecoxib

Explanation:

Rofecoxib and Valdecoxib, selective COX-2 inhibitors, were withdrawn from the market due to their association with a higher risk of atherothrombotic events.

  • COX-2 inhibitors reduce endothelial PGI2 production without affecting platelet TXA2 synthesis → Prothrombotic state → Increased cardiovascular risk.
  • Hence, they should be reserved for high-risk peptic ulcer patients at the lowest dose and shortest duration and avoided in patients with a risk of heart disease.

Aspirin and Naproxen (Options A and B): are safer for cardiovascular patients due to their antiplatelet effects. Aspirin irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation primarily by inhibiting COX-1, which reduces the risk of cardiovascular events. Similarly, Naproxen's longer half-life and COX inhibition contribute to cardiovascular safety.

Nefopam (Option C): doesn't act on the COX enzyme. It is a serotonin-norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor (SNDRI). It is used to treat migraines and post-anesthetic shivering. It is not known to cause cardiovascular events like STEMI.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a slowly progressive, verrucous plaque on her left foot. She has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis treated several years ago. On examination, the lesion appears well-defined, hyperkeratotic, and verrucous, with a papillomatous surface as shown in the image. All of the following statements are true about this condition except?

choices.text: Anatomist's wart is the other name
Antitubercular therapy is used in the management

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Post-primary tuberculosis with poor immunity.

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario and the image suggest the diagnosis of Tuberculosis verrucous cutis which is also known as Prosecutor's wart, Anatomist's wart (Option A), Verruca necrogenica, and Warty tuberculosis.
  • It is a form of Cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs after direct inoculation of the mycobacteria into the skin of a previously sensitized host with good immunity against the bacillus. (Option B)
  • It is a paucibacillary lesion (Option C), and inoculation typically occurs from an exogenous source.
  • In adults, TBVC most frequently develops on the acral extremities; the fingers and dorsum of the hands are commonly affected, while in children, the ankles or buttocks are frequent sites for lesion occurrence.
  • It presents as a painless, slowly progressive, red or brown warty, hyperkeratotic plaque with a verrucous or papillomatous surface and it grows via peripheral extension.
  • On histopathological examination, it is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with epithelioid histiocytes, giant cells, and caseous necrosis(caseating granulomas).
  • It can be treated with Antitubercular drugs (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication of expectant management of unruptured tubal pregnancy?

choices.text: The initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L
Gestation sac size less than 4 cm
No evidence of bleeding on USG

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Initial beta hCG level is less than 2500 IU/L


Explanation:
Indications for expectant management of ectopic pregnancy (only monitoring hCG levels without any interventions):

  • Initial serum hCG level is less than 1,500 IU/L and subsequent levels are decreasing.
  • Gestational sac size is less than 4 cm (Option C)
  • Absence of fetal heartbeat detected (Option B) on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS).
  • No evidence of bleeding (Option D) or rupture on transvaginal ultrasound (TVS)

questions.text: A 32 year old man presents to the clinic with a rash on his neck and upper chest area after spending the day on his farm in hot and humid weather. He describes the rash as itchy and prickly. On examination, there are numerous small, erythematous papules present, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Miliaria rubra


Explanation:

Miliaria rubra (prickly heat or heat rash) arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts at the level of stratum spinosum in hot, humid conditions, resulting in sweat leakage into the epidermis.

It is characterized by small, red papules or vesicles accompanied by itching or a prickling sensation. It typically occurs in areas of the body prone to sweating and friction during hot and humid weather.

 

Miliaria crystallina (Option A)

Miliaria profunda (Option C)

Miliaria pustulosa (Option D)
  • Obstruction of eccrine sweat duct at the level of stratum corneum.
  • Seen in infants and are characterized by clear fluid thin vesicles that may rupture easily, leaving behind superficial peeling or desquamation.
  • Obstruction of eccrine sweat duct at Dermo-epidermal junction.
  • It is characterized by firm, flesh-coloured lesions or bumps beneath the skin's surface.
  • It follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra.

 
  • It is an infected variant of miliaria rubra by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It is characterized by pustules or pus-filled lesions in addition to the typical features of miliaria rubra.

questions.text: A patient experiences persistent shoulder pain and weakness after a fall. An MRI reveals a full-thickness rotator cuff tear. Which statement correctly describes the classification of rotator cuff tears?

choices.text: Full-thickness tears involve bursal side tear, within tendon substance
Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side
Full-thickness tears are typically caused by overuse and repetitive stress
Partial-thickness tears develop gradually due to impingement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Partial-thickness tears can occur on the articular side or bursal side.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Rotator Cuff Anatomy and Tear Classification

Anatomy of the Rotator Cuff

  • Muscles Involved:
    • Supraspinatus
    • Infraspinatus
    • Teres minor
    • Subscapularis (collectively known as SITS)

Anterior view:

Posterior view:

  • Functions:
    • Stabilizes the shoulder joint
    • Assists in arm rotation and lifting
    • Controls shoulder blade movement

Role of Specific Muscles

  • Supraspinatus & Infraspinatus:
    • Keep the humeral head secure in the glenoid during arm abduction.
  • Subscapularis:
    • Stabilizes the front of the shoulder joint.
    • Prevents anterior dislocation of the humeral head.

Classification of Rotator Cuff Tears

Type

Description

Common Causes

Partial-Thickness Tears

Involve damage to some fibers of the tendon; can occur on:

Bursal side (top)

Articular side (bottom)

Within tendon substance (Option A ruled out) (Option B)

Overuse, repetitive stress (Option C ruled out)

Full-Thickness Tears

Complete rupture of the tendon; not attached to the bone

Sudden injuries (e.g., falls), gradual development due to stress or impingement (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is being demonstrated in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nikolsky's sign

Explanation:

The above image shows a firm sliding tangential pressure with a finger separating superficial epidermis layer from basal epidermis , producing an erosion called the Nikolsky sign.

 

Disease process

Associated diseases

True Nikolsky’s sign

Acantholysis

Pemphigus foliaceous, Pemphigus Vulgaris, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Pseudo Nikolsky’s sign

Necrosis of keratinocytes

Toxic epidermal Necrolysis

Stevens-Johnson syndrome

Bulla spread (Option B): Slow and careful unidirectional pressure applied by a finger to the bulla causes the bulla to extend beyond the original margin as shown below. Extension of bulla is in V Shape in Pemphigus Vulgaris and Oval shape in Bullous Pemphigoid

Auspitz sign (Option C): Removal of the thinned supra papillary epidermis by gentle scraping (K/a Grattage test) will reveal vascular bleeding points as seen in Psoriasis. Its is sue to inflamed blood vessels in papillary dermis which are present below epidermis psoriatic scales

 

Koebner phenomenon (Option D) refers to the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin in patients with certain skin diseases, such as psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo.

Pseudokoebner phenomenon: seen due to autoinocculation in warts (HPV) , Molluscum contagiosum

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to poor weight gain, vomiting, and yellowing of the skin and eyes. Genetic testing confirms a deficiency in fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. The physician recommends a low-protein diet and the drug Nitisinone. Which of the following is not an indication of Nitisinone?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Tyrosinemia type II

Explanation:

  • Nitisinone inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase, preventing toxic metabolite buildup in tyrosine metabolism.

  • Indications: Tyrosinemia type I, Alkaptonuria, Hawkinsinuria.

  • Tyrosinemia type II is due to tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency and is not treated with Nitisinone.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Posterior uveitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Iridocyclitis

 

Explanation:

Posterior uveitis is defined as the inflammation of the choroid and the retina. The components of posterior uveitis include the following,

  • Choroiditis
  • Retinitis
  • Retinal vasculitis
    • Periphlebitis - Venous sheathing
    • Periarteritis - Hemorrhages

 

Causes of Posterior Uveitis:
 

Category

Examples

Infectious Causes

Viruses: CMV, HSV, herpes zoster, rubella, measles

Bacteria: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Brucella spp., Borrelia burgdorferi, other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria

Fungi: Candida spp., Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces spp., Cryptococcus neoformans, Aspergillus spp.

Parasites: Toxoplasma gondii, Toxocara spp., Onchocerca volvulus, Acanthamoeba spp.

Non-Infectious Causes

Autoimmune: Behçet's disease, VKH syndrome, SLE, Wegener's granulomatosis, sympathetic ophthalmia

Malignancy: Intraocular lymphoma, malignant melanoma, leukemia

Unknown Etiology: Sarcoidosis, serpiginous choroiditis, Birdshot chorioretinopathy, retinal pigmented epitheliopathy

 

Clinical Features of Posterior Uveitis

Type

Features

Symptoms

Defective Vision: Ranges from mild blurriness to severe vision loss

Photopsia: Flashes of light from retinal irritation

Floaters: Black spots or cobwebs due to vitreous debris

Metamorphopsia: Distorted vision, with straight lines appearing wavy

Scotoma: Blind spot or reduced vision area in the visual field

Signs

Vitreous Opacities: Fine or coarse opacities, "snowballs", or strands in the vitreous humor

Active Chorioretinal Lesions: Pale yellow or white, raised areas with blurred margins; possible retinal haziness and vasculitis 

Healed Chorioretinal Lesions: White, atrophic areas with choroidal thinning; black pigment clumping at edges 

 

Note: Posterior uveitis is typically painless, unlike anterior uveitis, which often presents with pain, redness, and photophobia.

questions.text: In drug mechanisms observed in cancer cells, which of the following accurately describes the role of the P-glycoprotein pump (Pgp)?

choices.text: Pgp facilitates drug uptake into tumour cells
Pgp reduces drug elimination from tumour cells
Pgp is involved in drug efflux from tumour cells
Pgp has no significant impact on drug transport within tumour cells

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Pgp is involved in drug efflux from tumour cells
 

Explanation:

P-glycoprotein (P-gp), also known as ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1) or multidrug resistance protein 1 (MDR1), is an efflux transporter protein.

  • Its primary function is to pump out a wide range of substances, including drugs, from inside the cell to outside the cell (drug efflux). (Options: A, B, and D ruled out).
  • When Pgp is overexpressed or hyperactive in cancer cells, it leads to increased efflux of chemotherapeutic drugs out of the cells (leads to drug resistance).
  • Location of Pgp in various body tissues:
    • GIT: Decreases absorption of the drug.
    • Kidney: Increases urinary excretion of the drug.
    • Liver: Increases bile excretion of the drug.
    • Blood-brain-barrier/Placenta: Decreases drug entry into the brain/placental cells.
  • Substrate of p-glycoprotein transporter: E.g. Digoxin.
 

P-glycoprotein Inducer

P-glycoprotein Inhibitor

Activity

Increases the activity of Pgp

Decreases the activity of Pgp

Drugs
  • Rifampicin.
  • Phenobarbitone.

Mnemonic: QVACKER

  • Quinidine
  • Verapamil
  • Amiodarone
  • Clarithromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Erythromycin
  • Ritonavir

Combined with Substrate

of p-glycoprotein

(Digoxin)

Increases the activity of P-gp.

  • Increased urinary excretion.
  • Digoxin is excreted.

Reduces the activity of P-gp.

  • Reduced urinary excretion.
  • Increased plasma concentration of the drug.
  • Toxicity of digoxin: Arrhythmias.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. His medical history includes cirrhosis. Physical examination reveals peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory tests show:
Serum sodium: 128 mEq/L
Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
Total protein: 5.5 g/dL (low)
Albumin: 2.8 g/dL (low)

Which of the following best describes the type of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypervolemic hyponatremia

Explanation:
The patient has signs of fluid overload (edema, ascites), indicating hypervolemic hyponatremia. Cirrhosis is one of the causes of hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Causes of Hyponatremia

Hypovolemic

(Option A)
  • GI/skin losses
  • Renal losses:
    • Intake of diuretics
    • Underlying renal conditions:
      • Nephronophthisis
      • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease
      • Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Sodium loss through urine

Euvolemic

(Option B)
  • SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone)
  • Glucocorticoid deficiency
  • Hypothyroidism

Hypervolemic
  • Conditions with lots of third spacing or edema
  • Total fluid in body is increasing but fluid in intravascular compartment may not be much
  • Specific conditions:
    • Cardiac failure
    • Cirrhosis of liver
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Hypoalbuminemia
    • Renal failure

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with difficulty performing fine voluntary movements of his right hand following a midbrain stroke. Neurological examination suggests involvement of pathways controlling distal limb muscles. Which of the following extra-pyramidal tracts contributes to the motor pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Rubrospinal tract

 

Explanation:

  • The rubrospinal tract is part of the lateral motor pathway that controls distal muscles and fine voluntary movements, making it responsible for the deficits observed.
 

Lateral motor pathway

Medial motor pathway

Comprises of:
  • Corticospinal tract
  • Rubrospinal tract
  • Reticulospinal tract
  • Vestibulospinal tract
  • Tectospinal tract

Pathway and control
  • Terminates in the dorsolateral area of spinal gray matter and controls distal muscles
  • Terminates in ventromedial area of spinal gray matter and controls axial and proximal muscles

Function
  • Fine, skilled, voluntary motor movements
  • Maintaining erect posture

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles. Her workup reveals low estrogen levels but normal androgen levels. According to the two-cell two-gonadotropin theory, which hormone is likely insufficient in stimulating the conversion of androgens to estrogens in her granulosa cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) FSH

 

Explanation:

According to the Two-cell Two-gonadotropin theory:

  • The ovary has two cellular components: Theca cells and Granulosa cells.
  • Theca cells → express receptors for LH.

Granulosa cells → express receptors for FSH.

  • LH stimulation of theca cells → production of androgens (testosterone, androstenedione).
  • FSH stimulation of granulosa cells→ conversion of these androgens to estrogens (estradiol, estrone) through the aromatase enzyme.

LH (Option A) stimulates androgen production in the theca cells, not the conversion to estrogen.

 

Prolactin (Option C) is involved in lactation and has no direct role in converting androgens to estrogens.

 

GnRH (Option D) regulates the release of FSH and LH but is not directly involved in the conversion process within the ovarian cells.

questions.text: An appendix specimen, whose HPE is shown below, had a 2 cm submucosal nodule identified. Electron microscopy showed numerous neurosecretory granules in the cytoplasm. Twenty-four-hour urine analysis showed an elevation of 5-hydroxy indoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). Which of the following would not be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Bronchodilation

Explanation:

  • A submucosal nodule with neurosecretory granules on electron microscopy and elevated 5-HIAA confirms a neuroendocrine (carcinoid) tumor of the appendix, typically at the tip, and it is not associated with bronchodilation

Image showing cells arranged in the form of a rosette (cells in nests)

Image showing salt and pepper chromatin

Carcinoid tumors:

  • Derived from Argentaffin cells that secrete serotonin. It is commonly caused by neuroendocrine tumours of the midgut that metastasise to the liver. It is also seen with ovarian tumours or bronchial carcinoids. They secrete mediators like serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), kallikrein, bradykinin, histamine, and prostaglandins.
  • Clinical features:
    • S - Systemic fibrosis
    • H - Hepatomegaly, Heart disorders (valvular heart disorders - tricuspid regurgitation) (Option C ruled out)
    • I - Intestinal motility increases (diarrhoea, abdominal cramping) (Option B ruled out)
    • V - Vasodilation (flushing, pruritus) (Option A ruled out)
    • A - Asthma-like features - wheezing, dyspnea (bronchoconstriction) (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with episodes of severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Imaging reveals a large adrenal mass and biochemical tests confirm elevated plasma metanephrines. Further genetic testing shows a mutation in the SDHB gene. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (HPPS)

 

Explanation:

The presence of an SDHB gene mutation, along with symptoms of severe headaches, palpitations, sweating, imaging showing a large adrenal mass, and elevated plasma metanephrines, is most consistent with Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndrome (HPPS).

  • It encompasses germline mutations in several genes, including SDH subunits.
  • SDHB mutations are particularly noted for their association with high rates of malignant pheochromocytomas and extra-adrenal tumors.
    • These mutations lead to the accumulation of Krebs cycle intermediates, promoting tumorigenesis.
  • Patients with SDHB mutations are at high risk for malignant extra-adrenal (abdominal or thoracic) tumors, making it the most likely syndrome in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: The imaging below shows a double density sign in the paranasal sinuses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The double density sign on CT imaging of the paranasal sinuses is characteristic of allergic fungal sinusitis, indicating the presence of centrally hyperdense fungal material within the sinuses.

 

Allergic fungal sinusitis:

Etiopathogenesis
  • Allergic reaction to fungal organism (usually Aspergillus)

Clinical presentation
  • Age: 20-40 year females
  • B/L nasal polyposis: causing nasal obstruction
  • Characteristic peanut butter discharge: due to thick eosinophilic mucus

Bent & Kuhn criteria (used for Diagnosis)

Major criteria

Minor criteria
  • Type-I Hypersensitivity
  • Nasal polyposis
  • Characteristic CT findings
  • Eosinophilic mucin
  • Positive fungal stain
  • Asthma
  • Unilateral disease
  • Bone erosion (X-ray)
  • Serum eosinophilia
  • Positive fungal culture
  • Charcot-leyden crystals

Radiology

CT: Double density sign

questions.text: If a healthcare provider temporarily uses a domestic refrigerator to store vaccines, where should he place the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) and Measles vaccines inside the refrigerator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Top shelf

Explanation:

Appropriate placement is essential to maintain the cold chain.

  • Heat-sensitive vaccines, such as OPV, BCG and Measles vaccines, are best stored on the top shelf, as they provide a more stable temperature and reduce the risk of freezing, which can occur in colder areas like the bottom shelf or door shelves.

Domestic Refrigerator Usage

Details

Vaccine Storage

Can be used for storing vaccines at private clinics and nursing homes, but hold-over time and capacity are limited. Requires a guaranteed continuous power supply.

Temperature Range

Maintains a cabinet temperature between +2°C to +8°C.

Placement of Vaccines
(Options A, B, C, D)
  • Top Shelf: Measles, BCG, Rotavirus vaccine, OPV
  • Middle Shelf: DPT, Pentavalent vaccine, TT, IPV, Hepatitis B, and diluents placed next to their corresponding vaccines.
  • Bottom Shelf: Water-filled ice packs to help maintain temperature stability.
  • Door: Avoid storing vaccines in the door as they experience the most temperature fluctuation

Ice Pack Usage

Place ice packs filled with water on the bottom shelf and in the refrigerator door to help maintain the temperature in case of a power outage.

Temperature Monitoring

A dial thermometer is placed inside the refrigerator to monitor the temperature twice daily.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with polyuria, growth failure, fair skin, blond hair, and photophobia. Slit-lamp examination reveals cystine crystals in the cornea. Which genetic mutation is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CTNS

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario is that of Cystinosis.

Cystinosis

Etiology

Mutations in the CTNS gene (Option C) (encoding the protein cystinosin, a cystine transporter) → Defect in cystinosin → Accumulation of cystine crystals in major organs (kidney, liver, eyes, brain)

Clinical Features

  • Renal: Fanconi syndrome, polyuria, polydipsia, rickets, growth failure

  • Skin/Hair: Fair skin, blond hair

  • Eyes: Photophobia, retinopathy, ↓ visual acuity

  • Other: Fever (↓ sweating), hypothyroidism, hepatosplenomegaly, delayed puberty

Diagnosis
  • Detection of cystine crystals in the cornea.
  • Confirmed by measuring increased cystine content in leukocytes.

Treatment
  • Therapy with cysteamine (converts cystine to cysteine)
  • Cysteamine eye drops for ocular involvement.

questions.text: A patient presented with a hard mass over the right tibia, and subsequent imaging revealed the presence of sessile growth in the bone. Biopsy is done later, which shows the presence of “cartilage cap” over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Osteochondroma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation is suggestive of osteochondroma, characterised by the presence of cartilage cap over the lesion and sessile growth in the bone, which means the lesion has both bone and cartilage elements together.

 

Osteochondroma (Exostosis):

  • Osteochondroma is one of the most common benign bone tumors, also called exosurface.
  • It looks like a mushroom-like growth coming out of the bone and is in exact continuity with the underlying bone.
  • In osteochondroma, the tumor’s medulla is continuous with the bone medulla (inner part) and its cortex with the bone cortex (outer part), but it is covered by a cartilage cap, which distinguishes it and gives it the name osteochondroma.
  • Histology: It resembles a disorganized growth plate, and they undergo enchondral ossification, with the newly formed bone making up the inner portion of the head and stalk.

questions.text: A 9 year old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to difficulties in school. After a thorough evaluation, the diagnosis of ADHD is confirmed. The parents are concerned about medication and ask about the first line of treatment. What is the most effective first-line treatment for managing this child?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Stimulant medications

 

Explanation:

Stimulant medications, such as methylphenidate and amphetamines, are considered the first-line treatment for ADHD.

 

Pharmacologic treatment is considered the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first choice of agents in that they have the highest efficacy with generally mild tolerable side effects.

Parent training programs (Option B): While parent training helps manage ADHD symptoms, especially behavioural aspects, it is usually part of a broader treatment plan, not the first-line treatment.

 

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) (Option D): CBT is beneficial for older children and adolescents, helping them develop coping strategies. Psychosocial interventions usually are activities involving paying attention, waiting for their turn, and following instructions. However, it is not the primary treatment in younger children with ADHD.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and difficulty walking. His parents report a family history of similar symptoms. A detailed history was obtained, and a pedigree analysis was done, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis and the inheritance pattern seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D) Duchenne muscular dystrophy, X-linked recessive
 

EXPLANATION:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disease.

 

X-linked recessive disorders:

  • Females (XX) are carriers.

Males are affected by the disease.

Examples of X-linked recessive disorders:

Mnemonic

Diseases

Wise
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

AB
  • Hemophilia A, B
  • Ocular albinism

B
  • Bruton’s agammaglobulinemia
  • Becker muscular dystrophy

C
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Color blindness (Red-green)

D
  • Duchenne Muscular dystrophy

E

F
  • Fabry disease
  • Fragile-X syndrome (X-linked recessive > X-linked recessive)

G

H

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a large tumor involving the floor of the maxillary sinus, causing facial swelling and nasal obstruction. During surgery, the surgical team uses the approach shown in the image. Identify the type of incision used in this procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Weber-Fergusson Incision

Explanation:

 

 

  • Weber-Fergusson Approach: Provides access to the maxilla and periorbital area.
    • Used for extensive tumors in the maxillary sinus floor. (Option B)

 

Caldwell-Luc incision (Option A) is placed 3 mm above the line of reflection and runs laterally for 3.5 - 4 cm parallel to the teeth, starting at the canine ridge.

  • It is used for the surgical treatment of the severely diseased maxillary sinus.

Modified Blair incision (Option C) is for parotid surgery. I

  • t combines the inverted L-shaped preauricular incision of Blair with a cervical limb extending into the neck.

Lateral rhinotomy incision (Option D) is placed in the nasofacial groove.

  • Lateral rhinotomy is an established approach to the midfacial skeleton.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male presents with progressive fatigue, recurrent headaches, blurred vision, and episodes of epistaxis for the past 2 months. On examination, there is pallor and mild hepatosplenomegaly.  Labs are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 


	Hb: 8.5 g/dL
	Serum protein electrophoresis: M spike in the β–γ region
	Immunofixation: IgM monoclonal protein
	Bone marrow: infiltration with small lymphocytes and plasma cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia

Explanation:

Diagnosis of Waldenström macroglobulinemia are:

  1. IgM monoclonal spike, which is a hallmark of WM and causes hyperviscosity syndrome (headache, blurred vision, epistaxis, retinal changes)
  2. Bone marrow: lymphoplasmacytic infiltration.
  3. Splenomegaly is common in WM but rare in classic multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma (Option A): Incorrect because it typically involves an M protein that is IgG or IgA, not IgM.

Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (Option B): Incorrect, as it typically doesn't present with an IgM M spike or hyperviscosity syndrome.

Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (Option D): Incorrect, as it is a common condition with an M spike but lacks the clinical symptoms and organ damage seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with redness, mild swelling, and foreign body sensation in the right eye for 2 days. On examination, no visual impairment is noted, and a diagnosis of acute conjunctivitis is made. Which of the following is not a common sign of conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)

 

Explanation:

Ciliary congestion, also known as ciliary injection, is not a sign of conjunctivitis. It refers to deep, radial vessel congestion around the limbus, usually associated with intraocular conditions like iritis, keratitis, or acute glaucoma. The vessels here are part of the deeper structure of the eye, unlike the superficial vessels involved in conjunctivitis.

 

Symptoms and Signs of Conjunctivitis:

  • Hyperemia or redness of the conjunctiva (Option B)
  • Pain
  • Photophobia (rare, associated corneal involvement or iritis can be present)
  • Blepharospasm
  • Discharge (prominent feature)
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage (Option C)
  • Chemosis or conjunctival edema (Option A)
  • Inflammatory reactions: Follicles (localized aggregation of lymphocytes), papillae (hyperplasia of the normal vascular system), granulomas
  • Pseudomembranes/True membranes

 

Feature

Conjunctival Congestion

Ciliary Congestion

Location of Congestion

Confined to the conjunctiva, often more marked in the fornices.

Involves the area around the corneal margin, known as the limbal region.

On moving conjunctiva

Congested vessels also move

Congested vessels do not move

Common Causes

Bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, viral conjunctivitis

Acute iridocyclitis, acute glaucoma, keratitis, corneal ulcer.

Image

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with complaints of glare and diminution of vision for 3 months. On examination, you notice the following appearance



Choose the correct statement regarding the correct diagnosis.

choices.text: The Iris shadow test becomes positive only when the whole cortex is involved.
Patients see better in dark surroundings.
Characterized by saucer-shaped opacities in the center of the posterior cortex.
Vision loss occurs at a late stage.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vision loss occurs at a late stage.

Explanation:

An elderly patient with clinical features (glare/ diminution of vision/ blurred vision) suggestive of cataract and characteristic wedge-shaped opacities starting from periphery to center are noted, which points to a diagnosis of Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract.

Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery). (Option D)
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils. (Option B)

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract). (Option C)
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

 

Stages of Cortical cataract:

 

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas(Option A)
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with six months of dysphagia, regurgitation, and a feeling of food getting stuck, often coughing while eating. A barium swallow study shows specific findings on the radiograph. Which muscle pairs define the anatomical boundaries of the observed dehiscence?

choices.text: Inferior constrictor along with upper esophageal muscle fibres

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus

 

Explanation:

  • The scenario and barium swallow findings suggest Zenker’s diverticulum, an outpouching occurring at a site known as Killian’s Dehiscence (often referred to as the "gateway of tears").
  • This space is formed by the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle: the thyropharyngeus (oblique fibres) and the cricopharyngeus (transverse fibres). This arrangement creates a triangular gap known as Killian’s dehiscence.

 

Zenker’s Diverticulum (Hypopharyngeal Pouch/Pharyngeal Pouch):

Description

An acquired, false, and pulsion diverticulum formed by the protrusion of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's dehiscence.

Clinical manifestations
  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Food getting stuck (leading to coughing while eating)
  • Aspiration
  • Halitosis (bad breath)

Investigation

Barium swallow reveals an outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa above the upper oesophagal sphincter, often with slow emptying of the diverticulum.

 

Management

  • Diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy: Surgical removal of the diverticulum and myotomy of the cricopharyngeal muscle.
  • Diverticular suspension: Dissection and inversion of the diverticulum with its apex pointing cranially.
  • Myotomy through stapler transection: Transoral insertion of a linear stapler to divide the septum between the diverticulum and the true oesophagal lumen.

Dohlman Procedure: Endoscopic technique involving division of the diverticulum wall and cricopharyngeal myotomy.

 

 

Cricopharyngeus and esophageal muscle fibres (Option A): Incorrect because Zenker’s diverticulum arises above the esophagus, not between these structures.

Thyropharyngeus and esophageal muscle fibres (Option B): Incorrect, as the esophagus lies inferior to the area of dehiscence.

Inferior constrictor along with upper esophageal muscle fibres (Option D): Incorrect because this does not specify the true anatomical gap (Killian’s dehiscence is between the two parts of the inferior constrictor, not between it and the esophagus).

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-sinusoidal cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Schistosomiasis

Explanation:

Schistosomiasis is one of the pre-sinusoidal intrahepatic Causes of Portal Hypertension.

  • Post-sinusoidal​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

    • Veno-occlusive disease

questions.text: Blood pressure of a 65-year-old male in the ICU crashes. ECG tracing shows Ventricular fibrillation. 200 J biphasic shock is given to patient. Which of the following is next best step for managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Start CPR  

Immediately after defibrillation, the rhythm takes some time to reset to normal. During this time, chest compressions must continue @30:2.

questions.text: A 25 year old Rh-negative woman presents to her obstetrician a day after she experienced a spontaneous miscarriage at 10 weeks gestation. She has no history of RhIG administration. What is the appropriate management to prevent Anti-D alloimmunization in this patient?

choices.text: No RhIG administration needed at this stage

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Administer 50 μg of RhIG intramuscularly

 

Explanation:

Pregnancy

Rh Anti-D dosing

First Trimester (Miscarriage, Abdominal trauma, Ectopic)

50 μg, administered within 72 hours. (Option B)

28 weeks

300 μg of RhIG

After delivery

300 μg of RhIG (ideally within 72 hours but can be given up to 4 weeks) (Option A)

 

  • The standard intramuscular dose of anti-D immune globulin, 300 μg or 1500 IU, will protect the average-sized mother from a fetal hemorrhage of up to 30 mL of fetal whole blood or 15 mL of fetal red cells.
  • RhIG administration (Option C) is recommended after pregnancy-related events like miscarriage to prevent Anti-D alloimmunization, regardless of gestational age .
  • Checking for fetomaternal hemorrhage (Option D) is not needed for sensitizing events before 20 weeks .

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is incidentally found to have a horseshoe kidney during an abdominal CT scan. She has no symptoms. Which of the following complications is she at highest risk for developing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pelviureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction

 

Explanation:

  • Horseshoe kidney increases the risk of PUJ obstruction due to the abnormal position of the kidneys and the associated vascular anomalies, which can compress the ureters and impair urine flow.

 

Horseshoe Kidney

  • Clinical Features:
    • Mostly asymptomatic.
    • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
    • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs)
    • Hydronephrosis
    • Hematuria
    • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.
  • Investigations:
    • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualization of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.
    • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
    • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
      • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."
      • High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

questions.text: A 33 y/o female with well-controlled diabetes reports four episodes of vulvovaginal candidiasis in the past year, presenting with itching, burning, and thick white discharge. Examination shows vulvar and vaginal erythema and swelling with curd-like discharge. A wet mount confirms Candida albicans. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommended treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Fluconazole 150 mg orally every 3 days for three doses
Fluconazole 150 mg orally every 3 days for three doses, followed by once weekly for six months
Fluconazole 150 mg orally as a single dose
Vaginal boric acid capsules 600 mg daily for 14 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fluconazole 150 mg orally every 3 days for three doses, followed by once weekly for six months

 

Explanation:

The clinical vignette suggests recurrent C. albicans candidiasis.

Recurrent Candida albicans Candidiasis:

  • Treatment: Oral fluconazole 100-mg, 150-mg, or 200-mg doses once every third day for three doses (days 1, 4, and 7) or local intravaginal therapy for 7 to 14 days.
  • Prevention: Oral fluconazole 100 to 200 mg weekly for 6 months.

 

Recurrent Non-albicans Candida Species:

  • Treatment: Boric acid 600 mg gelatin capsule intravaginally at bedtime for 2 weeks

questions.text: A 28 year old pregnant woman at 37 weeks gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine check-up. On abdominal examination, the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, and the pelvic grip is empty. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a normal baseline with reassuring variability. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) External cephalic version

Explanation:

In the given scenario, the pregnant woman presents at 37 weeks, the fetal head is not engaged, and the fetal status is stable, which is in a transverse lie. An external cephalic version could be the appropriate next step in management to attempt to reposition the fetus for a potential vaginal delivery.

  • M/c cause of transverse lie - Prematurity
  • It has high risk of cord prolapse
  • Antenatal Management: If there are no contraindications, attempt an external cephalic version (ECV) beyond 35 weeks for the transverse lie.
  • If Version Fails or is Contraindicated: Elective cesarean section (Option D) is the preferred delivery method.
  • Management in Labor: In early labor, try an external cephalic version (ECV) if appropriate or opt for cesarean section if ECV is unsuccessful. In late labor, ECV is usually impractical due to ruptured membranes, so the cesarean section is preferred in such cases.
  • Internal Version Considerations: Only for specific cases like managing the second twin.

Immediate induction of labour (Option A): The fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, which means the baby is not in a favourable position for a safe vaginal delivery. Attempting induction could increase the risk of complications such as cord prolapse or obstruction.

Vaginal delivery with careful monitoring (Option C): Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in transverse lie due to the risk of cord prolapse or obstructed labour.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) I-c, II-a, III-b

Explanation:

The nuclear changes seen in irreversible cell injury are as follows:
