Shrinking of the nucleus and clumping of nuclear chromatin

Karyorrhexis

Nuclear fragmentation

Karyolysis

Dissolution of the nucleus
Order of the Events: P - K - K: Pyknosis - Karyorrhexis - Karyolysis

questions.text: Which of the following factors will not potentiate the effect of neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hypercalcemia, Alkalosis

Explanation:

Both hypercalcemia and alkalosis can reduce the effectiveness of neuromuscular blockers thus shortening their effects.

 

Factors That Potentiate the Effect of Neuromuscular Blockade

  1. Physiological changes in older adults
  2. Hypothermia (Option B ruled out)
  3. Hypermagnesemia (Option B ruled out)
  4. Hypocalcemia
  5. Acidosis
  6. Antimicrobials (aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, polymyxins, clindamycin) (Option C & D ruled out)
  7. Inhaled anesthetics
  8. Lithium (Option C ruled out)
  9. Local anaesthetics (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding bile acid synthesis regulation?


	7α-hydroxylation is the step which is suppressed
	Cholic acid suppresses the synthesis
	Farnesoid X receptor is activated
	Transcription of the CYP7A1 gene is suppressed
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1,3,4

Explanation:

  • Chenodeoxycholic acid (not cholic acid) is the most potent bile acid inhibitor.

  • It activates FXR, which suppresses CYP7A1 transcription, reducing 7α-hydroxylase activity (rate-limiting step).

  • This leads to ↓ bile acid synthesis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a sudden severe headache, brief loss of consciousness, nausea, and vomiting. Neurological examination shows decreased consciousness and mild focal deficits. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is provided. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

 

Explanation:

  • Given the clinical scenario and radiological findings showing a crescent-shaped blood collection that follows the brain's contours and crossing suture lines, the most probable diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma.

 

Features

Subdural Hematoma

Extradural Hematoma

(Option B)

Location

Between Dura and Arachnoid

Between Dura and Skull

CT Appearance
  • Crescent-shaped
  • Crosses suture lines
  • Biconvex or lens-shaped
  • Well-defined & Localized,
  • Won’t cross suture lines

Common Causes

Tearing of bridging veins, often due to blunt trauma / acceleration-deceleration injuries

Rupture of the middle meningeal artery or vein due to skull fracture or trauma

Onset

Develop over days to weeks; Acute SDH can occur rapidly

Usually develop rapidly

Management
  • Craniotomy / Craniectomy, if significant.
  • Conservative management for smaller, stable cases.
  • Burr hole drainage is preferred for significant chronic cases

Urgent surgical evacuation for significant or deteriorating cases.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic GERD undergoes endoscopy, which shows a 3 cm segment of salmon-colored mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Biopsy confirms intestinal metaplasia without dysplasia, and no nodularity or ulceration is seen.What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) High-dose proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and aspirin

Explanation:

Endoscopy findings are consistent with Barrett’s Esophagus - High-dose PPI therapy can reduce acid reflux and allow for mucosal healing, while aspirin has been shown to have a chemopreventive effect (combination can improve outcomes).

  • Treatment:
    • Treat underlying GERD, same pharmacological therapy as symptomatic GERD
    • Chemoprevention: Aspirin + high-dose PPI improves outcomes (Option C)
    • Dysplastic Treatment: Ablate/resect without invasive cancer, controversial in non-dysplastic
    • Ablative Therapy: Flat lesions only, RFA preferred
    • EMR vs ESD
      • EMR: easier, piecemeal;
      • ESD: en bloc, better margins
  • Post-Treatment: Surveillance for recurrence/persistent Barrett's or neoplasia

 

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with global developmental delay, hypotonia, and characteristic dysmorphic facial features. Karyotype analysis confirms trisomy 21. Given the genetic basis of the condition, which of the following additional findings is least likely to be directly associated with this disorder?

choices.text: Increased risk of early-onset Alzheimer's disease
Increased risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
Increased risk of congenital heart defects

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Increased risk of ataxia-telangiectasia

 

Explanation:

 

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.
  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.
  • The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis:

General Features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes with epicanthic folds, oblique palpebral fissure (visible when eyes are open).
  • Small nose with flat nasal bridge
  • Narrow palate, small teeth, and furrowed, protruding tongue
  • Significant hypotonia
  • Small, brachycephalic skull with flat occiput, and small, dysplastic ears
  • Short, broad hands with clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger)
  • Simian crease on the palm
  • A wide gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap)

Comorbidities

  • Congenital Heart Disease (Option D): 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases) - AVSD, VSD, ASD, PDA, TOF.
    • Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.
  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia.
    • There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.
  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues.
    • Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.
  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year.
    • Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.
  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.
  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age.
    • Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.
  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia (Option B), acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.
  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (Option A): The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Ataxia-telangiectasia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATM gene on chromosome 11, unrelated to trisomy 21. This condition involves progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias, and immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in his legs. He has had a history of intermittent facial flushing and diarrhea for the past several years. Physical examination reveals a new heart murmur. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Carcinoid heart disease

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of facial flushing, diarrhea, and a newly detected heart murmur, coupled with symptoms of right-sided heart failure (such as leg swelling and shortness of breath), strongly points toward carcinoid heart disease.
  • Carcinoid heart disease is a complication of carcinoid syndrome, which results from the release of serotonin and other vasoactive substances by a carcinoid tumor.

Pathophysiology:

  • Plaque-like deposits composed of smooth muscle cells, myofibroblasts, extracellular matrix and an overlying endothelial layer which lead to valve dysfunction.
  • Valvular dysfunction can lead to edema, ascites and right-sided heart failure.
  • Pulmonary heart disease primarily affects the right side of the heart.
  • Within the right heart, the tricuspid valve is the first to be affected, followed by the pulmonary valve.
  • Regurgitant lesions are more common than stenotic lesions.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in their decreasing order of penetration power

1) Neutrons

2) Alpha (α) rays

3) Beta (β) rays

4) Gamma (γ) rays
questions.solution:
Penetration power is maximum with Neutrons (1) > Gamma (γ) rays (4) > Beta (β) rays (3) > Alpha (α) rays (2). Hence, the correct answer is 1>4>3>2 (Option B).

 

Alpha (α), Beta (β) & Gamma (γ) rays:

Alpha (α) rays:

Particles emitted by the nucleus through α decay, containing 2 protons and 2 neutrons.

Beta (β) rays:

Particles emitted by the nucleus through β decay, either electrons/positrons

Gamma (γ) rays:

Photons emitted by the nucleus.

Ionizing power: (damaging capacity of linear energy transfer - LET)

Alpha (α) > Beta (β) > X-Rays > Gamma (γ) rays

Penetration power:

Neutrons > Gamma (γ)rays >Beta (β)rays >Alpha (α)rays

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a bladder tumor invading the muscle layer is classified as which TNM stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) T2

 

Explanation:

T2 lesions indicate invasion into the muscle layer of the bladder.
 

Primary Tumor Staging (TNM System)

The depth of invasion of the primary tumor in bladder cancer is a crucial prognostic factor for recurrence and progression.

Ta Lesions

(Option A)

Papillary (exophytic) tumors with a tendency to recur.

Tis Lesions

High-grade intraepithelial neoplasms (carcinoma in situ [CIS]) without invasion into subepithelial connective tissue.

T1 Lesions

(Option B)

Tumors invade the submucosa or lamina propria, typically high-grade.

T2 Lesions

(Option C)

Tumors invade muscle; cystectomy is standard therapy.

Presence of muscle invasion increases the likelihood of nodal and distant metastases.

T3 Lesions

(Option D)

Tumors extend beyond muscle into perivesical fat. Imaging (CT, MRI, PET) may help identify disease spread outside the bladder.

T4 Lesions

Tumors extend into adjacent organs.

T4a - invasion into the prostate, vagina, uterus, or bowel

T4b - tumors fixed to the abdominal wall, pelvic wall, or other organs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is scheduled for an ERCP using the contrast mentioned below. Which type of contrast agent is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Non-ionic Monomer

 

  • Iohexol is an iodine contrast agent that is classified as a Non-ionic monomer.
  • The commonly used iodine contrast agents are water soluble and are classified into ionic and non-ionic groups based on their osmolality and chemical structure.
  • The iodine particle ratio helps decide the osmolality of the drug, where high osmolar drugs pose a higher risk for kidney damage.

 

Iodine Particle Ratio
  • Ionic = 2 particles
  • Non-ionic = 1 particle
  • Monomer = 3 iodine
  • Dimer = 6 iodine

Ionic Monomer

Ionic Dimer

Non-ionic Monomer

Non-ionic Dimer

3:2

(High osmolality)

3:1

(Low osmolality)

3:1

6:1

Iodine Contrast

Routes of administration

Intravenous and Intra-arterial


 

Indications

Commonly used for contrast in CECT (3D X-ray), Interventional Radiology, and X-rays like as in

  • Intravenous pyelogram
  • Micturating cystourethrogram
  • Hysterosalpingography
  • Retrograde pyelography
  • ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

Adverse Reactions

Physiological Reactions

Allergic Reactions

Post-contrast induced nephropathy
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Flushing
  • Headaches
  • Vasovagal reaction
  • Arrhythmias
  • Seizures
 

-

Mild reactions:

  • Hives (Urticaria)
  • Erythema (Redness of skin)
 

Moderate to severe reactions:

  • Wheezing
  • Anaphylactoid reactions (Non-IgE mediated)
  • Also known as Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI).
  • It is defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Risk factors:
    • Patients with pre-existing kidney disease.
    • Pre-contrast eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m² indicates higher risk.

Management:

Observation for mild reactions

Management:

  • Mild reactions: Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine)
  • Severe reactions: Requires epinephrine and advanced airway management as needed.

Management:

Intravenous hydration (e.g., normal saline)
